You have to educate the population. And Sheikh Zayed did that in a fairly good way. In spite of falling oil prices, he brought this country up here. So we've got a much more mainstream appearance of the world, where all countries tend to use their money better than they used in the past.Now, this is, more or less, if you look at the average data of the countries — they are like this. Now that's dangerous, to use average data, because there is such a lot of difference within countries. So if I go and look here, we can see that Uganda today is where South Korea was in 1960. If I split Uganda, there's quite a difference within Uganda. These are the quintiles of Uganda. The richest 20 percent of Ugandans are there. The poorest are down there. If I split South Africa, it's like this. And if I go down and look at Niger, where there was such a terrible famine, lastly, it's like this. The 20 percent poorest of Niger is out here, and the 20 percent richest of South Africa is there, and yet we tend to discuss on what solutions there should be in Africa. Everything in this world exists in Africa. And you can't discuss universal access to HIV [medicine] for that quintile up here with the same strategy as down here. The improvement of the world must be highly contextualized, and it's not relevant to have it on regional level. We must be much more detailed. We find that students get very excited when they can use this.And even more, policy makers and the corporate sectors would like to see how the world is changing. Now, why doesn't this take place? Why are we not using the data we have? We have data in the United Nations, in the national statistical agencies and in universities and other non-governmental organizations. Because the data is hidden down in the databases. And the public is there, and the Internet is there, but we have still not used it effectively.All that information we saw changing in the world does not include publicly-funded statistics. There are some web pages like this, you know, but they take some nourishment down from the databases, but people put prices on them, stupid passwords and boring statistics.(Laughter)And this won't work.(Applause)So what is needed? We have the databases. It's not the new database you need. We have wonderful design tools, and more and more are added up here. So we started a nonprofit venture which, linking data to design, we called Gapminder, from the London Underground, where they warn you, "mind the gap." So we thought Gapminder was appropriate. And we started to write software which could link the data like this. And it wasn't that difficult. It took some person years, and we have produced animations. You can take a data set and put it there. We are liberating U.N. data, some few U.N. organization.Some countries accept that their databases can go out on the world, but what we really need is, of course, a search function. A search function where we can copy the data up to a searchable format and get it out in the world. And what do we hear when we go around? I've done anthropology on the main statistical units. Everyone says, "It's impossible. This can't be done. Our information is so peculiar in detail, so that cannot be searched as others can be searched. We cannot give the data free to the students, free to the entrepreneurs of the world."But this is what we would like to see, isn't it? The publicly-funded data is down here. And we would like flowers to grow out on the Net. And one of the crucial points is to make them searchable, and then people can use the different design tool to animate it there. And I have pretty good news for you. I have good news that the present, new Head of U.N. Statistics, he doesn't say it's impossible. He only says, "We can't do it."(Laughter)And that's a quite clever guy, huh?(Laughter)So we can see a lot happening in data in the coming years. We will be able to look at income distributions in completely new ways. This is the income distribution of China, 1970. This is the income distribution of the United States, 1970. Almost no overlap. And what has happened? What has happened is this: that China is growing, it's not so equal any longer, and it's appearing here, overlooking the United States. Almost like a ghost, isn't it?(Laughter)It's pretty scary.(Laughter)But I think it's very important to have all this information. We need really to see it. And instead of looking at this, I would like to end up by showing the Internet users per 1,000. In this software, we access about 500 variables from all the countries quite easily. It takes some time to change for this, but on the axises, you can quite easily get any variable you would like to have. And the thing would be to get up the databases free, to get them searchable, and with a second click, to get them into the graphic formats, where you can instantly understand them. Now, statisticians don't like it, because they say that this will not show the reality; we have to have statistical, analytical methods. But this is hypothesis-generating.I end now with the world. There, the Internet is coming. The number of Internet users are going up like this. This is the GDP per capita. And it's a new technology coming in, but then amazingly, how well it fits to the economy of the countries. That's why the $100 computer will be so important. But it's a nice tendency. It's as if the world is flattening off, isn't it? These countries are lifting more than the economy and will be very interesting to follow this over the year, as I would like you to be able to do with all the publicly funded data.Thank you very much.(Applause)

WEBVTT

00:00:12.584 --> 00:00:16.939
About 10 years ago, I took on the task
to teach global development

00:00:16.963 --> 00:00:18.986
to Swedish undergraduate students.

00:00:19.010 --> 00:00:21.930
That was after having spent about 20 years

00:00:21.954 --> 00:00:25.464
together with African institutions
studying hunger in Africa,

00:00:25.488 --> 00:00:29.407
so I was sort of expected
to know a little about the world.

00:00:29.431 --> 00:00:32.934
And I started in our medical university,
Karolinska Institute,

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:36.328
an undergraduate course
called Global Health.

00:00:36.352 --> 00:00:39.334
But when you get that opportunity,
you get a little nervous.

00:00:39.358 --> 00:00:41.233
I thought, these students coming to us

00:00:41.257 --> 00:00:44.769
actually have the highest grade
you can get in Swedish college systems --

00:00:44.793 --> 00:00:48.210
so I thought, maybe they know everything
I'm going to teach them about.

00:00:48.234 --> 00:00:49.934
So I did a pre-test when they came.

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:53.666
And one of the questions
from which I learned a lot was this one:

00:00:53.690 --> 00:00:57.628
"Which country has the highest
child mortality of these five pairs?"

00:00:58.779 --> 00:01:01.568
I put them together,
so that in each pair of country,

00:01:01.592 --> 00:01:05.387
one has twice the child
mortality of the other.

00:01:05.411 --> 00:01:09.656
And this means that
it's much bigger a difference

00:01:09.680 --> 00:01:11.351
than the uncertainty of the data.

00:01:11.375 --> 00:01:13.690
I won't put you at a test here,
but it's Turkey,

00:01:13.714 --> 00:01:17.934
which is highest there, Poland,
Russia, Pakistan and South Africa.

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:20.614
And these were the results
of the Swedish students.

00:01:20.638 --> 00:01:24.543
I did it so I got the confidence interval,
which is pretty narrow, and I got happy,

00:01:24.567 --> 00:01:27.358
of course: a 1.8 right answer
out of five possible.

00:01:27.382 --> 00:01:30.934
That means that there was a place
for a professor of international health

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:32.065
and for my course.

00:01:32.089 --> 00:01:33.207
(Laughter)

00:01:33.231 --> 00:01:36.934
But one late night,
when I was compiling the report,

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:39.790
I really realized my discovery.

00:01:39.814 --> 00:01:42.921
I have shown that Swedish top students

00:01:42.945 --> 00:01:47.934
know statistically significantly less
about the world than the chimpanzees.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:49.934
(Laughter)

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:53.188
Because the chimpanzee
would score half right

00:01:53.212 --> 00:01:56.071
if I gave them two bananas
with Sri Lanka and Turkey.

00:01:56.095 --> 00:01:59.517
They would be right half of the cases.
But the students are not there.

00:01:59.541 --> 00:02:03.756
The problem for me was not ignorance;
it was preconceived ideas.

00:02:03.780 --> 00:02:06.517
I did also an unethical study

00:02:06.541 --> 00:02:08.764
of the professors
of the Karolinska Institute,

00:02:08.788 --> 00:02:11.149
that hands out
the Nobel Prize in Medicine,

00:02:11.173 --> 00:02:13.364
and they are on par
with the chimpanzee there.

00:02:13.388 --> 00:02:16.412
(Laughter)

00:02:16.436 --> 00:02:20.619
This is where I realized that
there was really a need to communicate,

00:02:20.643 --> 00:02:23.545
because the data
of what's happening in the world

00:02:23.569 --> 00:02:26.740
and the child health
of every country is very well aware.

00:02:26.764 --> 00:02:29.684
We did this software
which displays it like this:

00:02:29.708 --> 00:02:31.489
every bubble here is a country.

00:02:31.513 --> 00:02:36.530
This country over here is China.

00:02:36.554 --> 00:02:37.555
This is India.

00:02:37.579 --> 00:02:39.843
The size of the bubble is the population,

00:02:39.867 --> 00:02:43.648
and on this axis here,
I put fertility rate.

00:02:43.672 --> 00:02:45.934
Because my students, what they said

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:48.767
when they looked upon the world,
and I asked them,

00:02:48.791 --> 00:02:51.137
"What do you really
think about the world?"

00:02:51.161 --> 00:02:54.703
Well, I first discovered
that the textbook was Tintin, mainly.

00:02:54.727 --> 00:02:55.876
(Laughter)

00:02:55.900 --> 00:02:58.415
And they said, "The world
is still 'we' and 'them.'

00:02:58.439 --> 00:03:01.407
And 'we' is Western world
and 'them' is Third World."

00:03:02.286 --> 00:03:04.849
"And what do you mean
with Western world?" I said.

00:03:04.873 --> 00:03:06.850
"Well, that's long life and small family,

00:03:06.874 --> 00:03:09.206
and Third World is short life
and large family."

00:03:10.016 --> 00:03:12.394
So this is what I could display here.

00:03:12.418 --> 00:03:15.794
I put fertility rate here:
number of children per woman:

00:03:15.818 --> 00:03:18.934
one, two, three, four,
up to about eight children per woman.

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:23.303
We have very good data
since 1962 -- 1960 about --

00:03:23.327 --> 00:03:25.360
on the size of families in all countries.

00:03:25.384 --> 00:03:26.759
The error margin is narrow.

00:03:26.783 --> 00:03:28.630
Here, I put life expectancy at birth,

00:03:28.654 --> 00:03:31.934
from 30 years in some countries
up to about 70 years.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:34.934
And 1962, there was really
a group of countries here

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:38.211
that was industrialized countries,

00:03:38.235 --> 00:03:40.559
and they had small families
and long lives.

00:03:40.583 --> 00:03:42.597
And these were the developing countries:

00:03:42.621 --> 00:03:45.699
they had large families
and they had relatively short lives.

00:03:45.723 --> 00:03:49.602
Now, what has happened since 1962?
We want to see the change.

00:03:49.626 --> 00:03:52.563
Are the students right?
Is it still two types of countries?

00:03:52.587 --> 00:03:56.146
Or have these developing countries
got smaller families and they live here?

00:03:56.170 --> 00:03:58.645
Or have they got longer lives
and live up there?

00:03:58.669 --> 00:04:00.510
Let's see. We stopped the world then.

00:04:00.534 --> 00:04:03.020
This is all U.N. statistics
that have been available.

00:04:03.044 --> 00:04:04.545
Here we go. Can you see there?

00:04:04.569 --> 00:04:07.856
It's China there, moving against
better health there, improving there.

00:04:07.880 --> 00:04:11.525
All the green Latin American countries
are moving towards smaller families.

00:04:11.549 --> 00:04:13.971
Your yellow ones here
are the Arabic countries,

00:04:13.995 --> 00:04:17.896
and they get longer life,
but not larger families.

00:04:17.920 --> 00:04:20.542
The Africans are the green here.
They still remain here.

00:04:20.566 --> 00:04:22.944
This is India; Indonesia
is moving on pretty fast.

00:04:22.968 --> 00:04:23.997
(Laughter)

00:04:24.021 --> 00:04:27.456
In the '80s here, you have Bangladesh
still among the African countries.

00:04:27.480 --> 00:04:30.433
But now, Bangladesh --
it's a miracle that happens in the '80s:

00:04:30.457 --> 00:04:32.934
the imams start to promote
family planning.

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.797
They move up into that corner.

00:04:34.821 --> 00:04:38.022
And in the '90s, we have
the terrible HIV epidemic

00:04:38.046 --> 00:04:41.652
that takes down the life expectancy
of the African countries

00:04:41.676 --> 00:04:44.934
and all the rest of them
move up into the corner,

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:49.872
where we have long lives and small family,
and we have a completely new world.

00:04:49.896 --> 00:04:53.110
(Applause)

00:05:00.837 --> 00:05:01.934
(Applause ends)

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:04.338
Let me make a comparison directly

00:05:04.362 --> 00:05:07.289
between the United States
of America and Vietnam.

00:05:07.313 --> 00:05:08.512
1964.

00:05:09.496 --> 00:05:12.107
America had small families and long life;

00:05:12.131 --> 00:05:15.257
Vietnam had large families
and short lives.

00:05:15.281 --> 00:05:16.949
And this is what happens:

00:05:16.973 --> 00:05:21.934
the data during the war indicate
that even with all the death,

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:24.111
there was an improvement
of life expectancy.

00:05:24.135 --> 00:05:27.099
By the end of the year,
the family planning started in Vietnam;

00:05:27.123 --> 00:05:28.690
they went for smaller families.

00:05:28.714 --> 00:05:31.605
And the United States up there
is getting for longer life,

00:05:31.629 --> 00:05:32.736
keeping family size.

00:05:32.760 --> 00:05:35.796
And in the '80s now,
they give up Communist planning

00:05:35.820 --> 00:05:37.779
and they go for market economy,

00:05:37.803 --> 00:05:39.804
and it moves faster even than social life.

00:05:39.828 --> 00:05:42.109
And today, we have in Vietnam

00:05:42.133 --> 00:05:46.804
the same life expectancy
and the same family size

00:05:46.828 --> 00:05:49.903
here in Vietnam, 2003,

00:05:49.927 --> 00:05:53.663
as in United States, 1974,
by the end of the war.

00:05:54.520 --> 00:05:57.767
If we don't look in the data,

00:05:57.791 --> 00:06:00.934
I think we all underestimate
the tremendous change in Asia,

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:05.727
which was in social change
before we saw the economical change.

00:06:05.751 --> 00:06:09.934
Let's move over to another way here
in which we could display

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:13.835
the distribution
in the world of the income.

00:06:13.859 --> 00:06:17.326
This is the world distribution
of income of people.

00:06:18.457 --> 00:06:21.934
One dollar, 10 dollars
or 100 dollars per day.

00:06:23.029 --> 00:06:26.370
There's no gap between rich
and poor any longer. This is a myth.

00:06:26.394 --> 00:06:28.409
There's a little hump here.

00:06:29.077 --> 00:06:30.934
But there are people all the way.

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:34.934
And if we look where the income ends up,

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:39.280
this is 100 percent
the world's annual income.

00:06:39.304 --> 00:06:41.767
And the richest 20 percent,

00:06:41.791 --> 00:06:45.665
they take out of that about 74 percent.

00:06:45.689 --> 00:06:50.840
And the poorest 20 percent,
they take about two percent.

00:06:50.864 --> 00:06:53.773
And this shows that the concept
of developing countries

00:06:53.797 --> 00:06:55.152
is extremely doubtful.

00:06:55.176 --> 00:06:56.934
We think about aid,

00:06:56.958 --> 00:07:00.906
like these people here giving aid
to these people here.

00:07:00.930 --> 00:07:03.568
But in the middle, we have
most of the world population,

00:07:03.592 --> 00:07:06.683
and they have now
24 percent of the income.

00:07:06.707 --> 00:07:10.477
We heard it in other forms.
And who are these?

00:07:10.501 --> 00:07:14.902
Where are the different countries?
I can show you Africa.

00:07:14.926 --> 00:07:16.350
This is Africa.

00:07:17.080 --> 00:07:19.744
10% the world population, most in poverty.

00:07:19.768 --> 00:07:21.781
This is OECD.

00:07:21.805 --> 00:07:24.388
The rich country.
The country club of the U.N.

00:07:24.412 --> 00:07:29.828
And they are over here on this side.
Quite an overlap between Africa and OECD.

00:07:29.852 --> 00:07:31.200
And this is Latin America.

00:07:31.224 --> 00:07:34.579
It has everything on this Earth,
from the poorest to the richest

00:07:34.603 --> 00:07:35.851
in Latin America.

00:07:35.875 --> 00:07:38.893
And on top of that,
we can put East Europe,

00:07:38.917 --> 00:07:42.306
we can put East Asia,
and we put South Asia.

00:07:42.330 --> 00:07:45.460
And how did it look like
if we go back in time,

00:07:45.484 --> 00:07:47.387
to about 1970?

00:07:47.411 --> 00:07:49.933
Then there was more of a hump.

00:07:51.112 --> 00:07:54.520
And we have most who lived
in absolute poverty were Asians.

00:07:54.544 --> 00:07:57.736
The problem in the world
was the poverty in Asia.

00:07:57.760 --> 00:08:00.934
And if I now let the world move forward,

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:03.708
you will see that
while population increases,

00:08:03.732 --> 00:08:06.801
there are hundreds of millions
in Asia getting out of poverty

00:08:06.825 --> 00:08:09.034
and some others getting into poverty,

00:08:09.058 --> 00:08:10.959
and this is the pattern we have today.

00:08:10.983 --> 00:08:13.054
And the best projection
from the World Bank

00:08:13.078 --> 00:08:14.812
is that this will happen,

00:08:14.836 --> 00:08:16.864
and we will not have a divided world.

00:08:16.888 --> 00:08:18.783
We'll have most people in the middle.

00:08:18.807 --> 00:08:20.712
Of course it's a logarithmic scale here,

00:08:20.736 --> 00:08:24.255
but our concept of economy
is growth with percent.

00:08:24.279 --> 00:08:29.327
We look upon it as a possibility
of percentile increase.

00:08:29.351 --> 00:08:34.278
If I change this, and take GDP per capita
instead of family income,

00:08:34.302 --> 00:08:38.028
and I turn these individual data

00:08:38.052 --> 00:08:41.094
into regional data
of gross domestic product,

00:08:41.118 --> 00:08:43.419
and I take the regions down here,

00:08:43.443 --> 00:08:45.682
the size of the bubble
is still the population.

00:08:45.706 --> 00:08:48.904
And you have the OECD there,
and you have sub-Saharan Africa there,

00:08:48.928 --> 00:08:50.934
and we take off the Arab states there,

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:54.934
coming both from Africa and from Asia,
and we put them separately,

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:59.934
and we can expand this axis,
and I can give it a new dimension here,

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:03.320
by adding the social values
there, child survival.

00:09:03.344 --> 00:09:05.508
Now I have money on that axis,

00:09:05.532 --> 00:09:08.225
and I have the possibility
of children to survive there.

00:09:08.249 --> 00:09:12.395
In some countries, 99.7% of children
survive to five years of age;

00:09:12.419 --> 00:09:14.144
others, only 70.

00:09:14.168 --> 00:09:17.243
And here, it seems,
there is a gap between OECD,

00:09:17.267 --> 00:09:20.512
Latin America, East Europe, East Asia,

00:09:20.536 --> 00:09:24.428
Arab states, South Asia
and sub-Saharan Africa.

00:09:24.452 --> 00:09:29.330
The linearity is very strong
between child survival and money.

00:09:29.354 --> 00:09:32.378
But let me split sub-Saharan Africa.

00:09:32.402 --> 00:09:37.623
Health is there
and better health is up there.

00:09:37.647 --> 00:09:41.934
I can go here and I can split
sub-Saharan Africa into its countries.

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.535
And when it burst,

00:09:43.559 --> 00:09:47.205
the size of its country bubble
is the size of the population.

00:09:47.229 --> 00:09:49.769
Sierra Leone down there.
Mauritius is up there.

00:09:49.793 --> 00:09:51.860
Mauritius was the first country

00:09:51.884 --> 00:09:55.285
to get away with trade barriers,
and they could sell their sugar --

00:09:55.309 --> 00:09:56.897
they could sell their textiles --

00:09:56.921 --> 00:10:00.561
on equal terms as the people
in Europe and North America.

00:10:00.585 --> 00:10:04.062
There's a huge difference between Africa.
And Ghana is here in the middle.

00:10:04.086 --> 00:10:06.934
In Sierra Leone, humanitarian aid.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:10.884
Here in Uganda, development aid.

00:10:10.908 --> 00:10:13.432
Here, time to invest;
there, you can go for a holiday.

00:10:13.456 --> 00:10:16.819
It's a tremendous variation within Africa

00:10:16.843 --> 00:10:19.934
which we rarely often make
-- that it's equal everything.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:23.934
I can split South Asia here.
India's the big bubble in the middle.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:28.420
But a huge difference
between Afghanistan and Sri Lanka.

00:10:28.444 --> 00:10:30.598
I can split Arab states. How are they?

00:10:30.622 --> 00:10:34.758
Same climate, same culture,
same religion -- huge difference.

00:10:34.782 --> 00:10:36.115
Even between neighbors.

00:10:36.139 --> 00:10:37.455
Yemen, civil war.

00:10:37.479 --> 00:10:41.822
United Arab Emirates, money,
which was quite equally and well used.

00:10:41.846 --> 00:10:43.331
Not as the myth is.

00:10:43.355 --> 00:10:46.528
And that includes all the children
of the foreign workers

00:10:46.552 --> 00:10:48.439
who are in the country.

00:10:49.242 --> 00:10:52.934
Data is often better than you think.
Many people say data is bad.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:56.101
There is an uncertainty margin,
but we can see the difference here:

00:10:56.125 --> 00:10:57.487
Cambodia, Singapore.

00:10:57.511 --> 00:11:00.482
The differences are much bigger
than the weakness of the data.

00:11:00.506 --> 00:11:05.153
East Europe: Soviet economy
for a long time,

00:11:05.177 --> 00:11:08.389
but they come out after 10 years
very, very differently.

00:11:08.413 --> 00:11:11.035
And there is Latin America.

00:11:11.059 --> 00:11:12.780
Today, we don't have to go to Cuba

00:11:12.804 --> 00:11:14.868
to find a healthy country
in Latin America.

00:11:14.892 --> 00:11:19.526
Chile will have a lower child mortality
than Cuba within some few years from now.

00:11:19.550 --> 00:11:22.605
Here, we have high-income
countries in the OECD.

00:11:22.629 --> 00:11:26.338
And we get the whole pattern
here of the world,

00:11:26.362 --> 00:11:28.408
which is more or less like this.

00:11:28.432 --> 00:11:33.523
And if we look at it, how the world looks,

00:11:33.575 --> 00:11:36.934
in 1960, it starts to move.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.527
This is Mao Tse-tung.
He brought health to China.

00:11:39.551 --> 00:11:40.685
And then he died.

00:11:40.709 --> 00:11:43.416
And then Deng Xiaoping came
and brought money to China,

00:11:43.440 --> 00:11:45.494
and brought them
into the mainstream again.

00:11:45.518 --> 00:11:49.676
And we have seen how countries
move in different directions like this,

00:11:49.700 --> 00:11:55.065
so it's sort of difficult to get
an example country

00:11:55.089 --> 00:11:57.748
which shows the pattern of the world.

00:11:57.798 --> 00:12:04.130
But I would like to bring you back
to about here, at 1960.

00:12:05.041 --> 00:12:08.331
I would like to compare

00:12:08.355 --> 00:12:15.045
South Korea, which is this one,
with Brazil, which is this one.

00:12:16.145 --> 00:12:17.926
The label went away for me here.

00:12:17.950 --> 00:12:20.546
And I would like to compare Uganda,
which is there.

00:12:21.649 --> 00:12:24.688
And I can run it forward, like this.

00:12:26.371 --> 00:12:33.338
And you can see how South Korea is making
a very, very fast advancement,

00:12:33.362 --> 00:12:35.934
whereas Brazil is much slower.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:42.292
And if we move back again, here,
and we put on trails on them, like this,

00:12:42.316 --> 00:12:45.934
you can see again
that the speed of development

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.772
is very, very different,

00:12:48.796 --> 00:12:55.497
and the countries are moving more or less
in the same rate as money and health,

00:12:55.521 --> 00:12:57.395
but it seems you can move much faster

00:12:57.419 --> 00:13:00.078
if you are healthy first
than if you are wealthy first.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:04.934
And to show that, you can put
on the way of United Arab Emirates.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.814
They came from here, a mineral country.

00:13:07.838 --> 00:13:10.163
They cached all the oil;
they got all the money;

00:13:10.187 --> 00:13:12.426
but health cannot be bought
at the supermarket.

00:13:13.474 --> 00:13:16.570
You have to invest in health.
You have to get kids into schooling.

00:13:16.594 --> 00:13:19.737
You have to train health staff.
You have to educate the population.

00:13:19.761 --> 00:13:22.215
And Sheikh Zayed did that
in a fairly good way.

00:13:22.239 --> 00:13:25.934
In spite of falling oil prices,
he brought this country up here.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:29.934
So we've got a much more mainstream
appearance of the world,

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.485
where all countries tend
to use their money

00:13:32.509 --> 00:13:34.620
better than they used in the past.

00:13:35.713 --> 00:13:42.685
Now, this is, more or less, if you look
at the average data of the countries --

00:13:42.709 --> 00:13:44.357
they are like this.

00:13:44.381 --> 00:13:47.723
Now that's dangerous, to use average data,

00:13:47.747 --> 00:13:51.518
because there is such
a lot of difference within countries.

00:13:51.542 --> 00:13:57.961
So if I go and look here,
we can see that Uganda today

00:13:57.985 --> 00:14:00.934
is where South Korea was in 1960.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:04.624
If I split Uganda, there's quite
a difference within Uganda.

00:14:04.648 --> 00:14:06.826
These are the quintiles of Uganda.

00:14:06.850 --> 00:14:09.034
The richest 20 percent
of Ugandans are there.

00:14:09.058 --> 00:14:10.443
The poorest are down there.

00:14:10.467 --> 00:14:13.343
If I split South Africa, it's like this.

00:14:13.367 --> 00:14:16.110
And if I go down and look at Niger,

00:14:16.134 --> 00:14:20.778
where there was such
a terrible famine, lastly, it's like this.

00:14:20.802 --> 00:14:23.696
The 20 percent poorest
of Niger is out here,

00:14:23.720 --> 00:14:26.489
and the 20 percent richest
of South Africa is there,

00:14:26.513 --> 00:14:28.531
and yet we tend to discuss

00:14:28.555 --> 00:14:30.934
on what solutions
there should be in Africa.

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.525
Everything in this world exists in Africa.

00:14:33.549 --> 00:14:36.824
And you can't discuss
universal access to HIV [medicine]

00:14:36.848 --> 00:14:41.220
for that quintile up here
with the same strategy as down here.

00:14:41.244 --> 00:14:44.782
The improvement of the world
must be highly contextualized,

00:14:44.806 --> 00:14:48.736
and it's not relevant to have it
on regional level.

00:14:48.760 --> 00:14:50.290
We must be much more detailed.

00:14:51.028 --> 00:14:54.354
We find that students get
very excited when they can use this.

00:14:54.378 --> 00:14:57.996
And even more, policy makers
and the corporate sectors

00:14:58.020 --> 00:15:01.681
would like to see
how the world is changing.

00:15:01.705 --> 00:15:03.393
Now, why doesn't this take place?

00:15:03.417 --> 00:15:05.907
Why are we not using the data we have?

00:15:05.931 --> 00:15:09.741
We have data in the United Nations,
in the national statistical agencies

00:15:09.765 --> 00:15:12.934
and in universities and other
non-governmental organizations.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:15.292
Because the data is hidden
down in the databases.

00:15:15.316 --> 00:15:18.248
And the public is there,
and the Internet is there,

00:15:18.273 --> 00:15:20.434
but we have still not used it effectively.

00:15:20.457 --> 00:15:22.934
All that information
we saw changing in the world

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:26.097
does not include
publicly-funded statistics.

00:15:26.121 --> 00:15:28.275
There are some web pages
like this, you know,

00:15:28.299 --> 00:15:32.934
but they take some nourishment
down from the databases,

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:37.934
but people put prices on them,
stupid passwords and boring statistics.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:39.347
(Laughter)

00:15:39.371 --> 00:15:40.546
And this won't work.

00:15:40.570 --> 00:15:43.373
(Applause)

00:15:43.397 --> 00:15:45.819
So what is needed? We have the databases.

00:15:45.843 --> 00:15:47.620
It's not the new database you need.

00:15:47.644 --> 00:15:51.370
We have wonderful design tools,
and more and more are added up here.

00:15:51.394 --> 00:15:54.265
So we started a nonprofit venture

00:15:54.289 --> 00:15:58.660
which, linking data to design,
we called Gapminder,

00:15:58.684 --> 00:16:00.037
from the London Underground,

00:16:00.061 --> 00:16:01.838
where they warn you, "mind the gap."

00:16:01.862 --> 00:16:03.802
So we thought Gapminder was appropriate.

00:16:03.826 --> 00:16:08.182
And we started to write software
which could link the data like this.

00:16:08.206 --> 00:16:09.753
And it wasn't that difficult.

00:16:09.777 --> 00:16:13.328
It took some person years,
and we have produced animations.

00:16:13.352 --> 00:16:15.685
You can take a data set and put it there.

00:16:15.709 --> 00:16:19.934
We are liberating U.N. data,
some few U.N. organization.

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:24.458
Some countries accept that
their databases can go out on the world,

00:16:24.482 --> 00:16:27.553
but what we really need is,
of course, a search function.

00:16:27.577 --> 00:16:31.934
A search function where we can copy
the data up to a searchable format

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:33.690
and get it out in the world.

00:16:33.714 --> 00:16:36.085
And what do we hear when we go around?

00:16:36.109 --> 00:16:39.116
I've done anthropology
on the main statistical units.

00:16:39.140 --> 00:16:42.260
Everyone says, "It's impossible.
This can't be done.

00:16:42.284 --> 00:16:44.794
Our information is so peculiar in detail,

00:16:44.818 --> 00:16:47.922
so that cannot be searched
as others can be searched.

00:16:47.946 --> 00:16:50.301
We cannot give the data
free to the students,

00:16:50.325 --> 00:16:52.230
free to the entrepreneurs of the world."

00:16:53.214 --> 00:16:56.109
But this is what we would
like to see, isn't it?

00:16:56.133 --> 00:16:58.557
The publicly-funded data is down here.

00:16:58.581 --> 00:17:01.616
And we would like flowers
to grow out on the Net.

00:17:01.640 --> 00:17:04.807
And one of the crucial points
is to make them searchable,

00:17:04.831 --> 00:17:09.075
and then people can use the different
design tool to animate it there.

00:17:09.099 --> 00:17:11.539
And I have pretty good news for you.

00:17:11.563 --> 00:17:13.757
I have good news that the present,

00:17:13.781 --> 00:17:16.934
new Head of U.N. Statistics,
he doesn't say it's impossible.

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:18.730
He only says, "We can't do it."

00:17:19.730 --> 00:17:22.934
(Laughter)

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:24.934
And that's a quite clever guy, huh?

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:26.934
(Laughter)

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:30.934
So we can see a lot happening
in data in the coming years.

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:35.618
We will be able to look at income
distributions in completely new ways.

00:17:35.642 --> 00:17:40.934
This is the income distribution
of China, 1970.

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:45.754
This is the income distribution
of the United States, 1970.

00:17:45.778 --> 00:17:48.827
Almost no overlap.

00:17:48.851 --> 00:17:50.301
And what has happened?

00:17:50.631 --> 00:17:52.309
What has happened is this:

00:17:52.333 --> 00:17:55.305
that China is growing,
it's not so equal any longer,

00:17:55.329 --> 00:17:58.934
and it's appearing here,
overlooking the United States.

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:01.616
Almost like a ghost, isn't it?

00:18:01.640 --> 00:18:02.934
(Laughter)

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:04.545
It's pretty scary.

00:18:04.569 --> 00:18:06.830
(Laughter)

00:18:09.720 --> 00:18:13.530
But I think it's very important
to have all this information.

00:18:13.554 --> 00:18:16.167
We need really to see it.

00:18:16.191 --> 00:18:18.934
And instead of looking at this,

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:24.606
I would like to end up by showing
the Internet users per 1,000.

00:18:24.630 --> 00:18:27.512
In this software, we access
about 500 variables

00:18:27.536 --> 00:18:29.937
from all the countries quite easily.

00:18:29.961 --> 00:18:32.934
It takes some time to change for this,

00:18:32.958 --> 00:18:38.813
but on the axises, you can quite easily
get any variable you would like to have.

00:18:38.837 --> 00:18:43.344
And the thing would be
to get up the databases free,

00:18:43.368 --> 00:18:45.934
to get them searchable,
and with a second click,

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:50.934
to get them into the graphic formats,
where you can instantly understand them.

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:53.060
Now, statisticians don't like it,

00:18:53.084 --> 00:19:00.052
because they say
that this will not show the reality;

00:19:00.076 --> 00:19:03.797
we have to have statistical,
analytical methods.

00:19:03.821 --> 00:19:05.934
But this is hypothesis-generating.

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:07.863
I end now with the world.

00:19:08.979 --> 00:19:10.464
There, the Internet is coming.

00:19:10.488 --> 00:19:12.971
The number of Internet users
are going up like this.

00:19:12.995 --> 00:19:14.964
This is the GDP per capita.

00:19:14.988 --> 00:19:18.473
And it's a new technology coming in,
but then amazingly,

00:19:18.497 --> 00:19:22.216
how well it fits to the economy
of the countries.

00:19:22.240 --> 00:19:25.697
That's why the $100 computer
will be so important.

00:19:25.721 --> 00:19:27.126
But it's a nice tendency.

00:19:27.150 --> 00:19:30.054
It's as if the world
is flattening off, isn't it?

00:19:30.078 --> 00:19:32.483
These countries are lifting more
than the economy

00:19:32.507 --> 00:19:35.292
and will be very interesting
to follow this over the year,

00:19:35.316 --> 00:19:38.677
as I would like you to be able to do
with all the publicly funded data.

00:19:38.701 --> 00:19:39.934
Thank you very much.

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:42.958
(Applause)

title: Why we do what we do
transcript: Thank you. I have to tell you I'm both challenged and excited. My excitement is: I get a chance to give something back. My challenge is: the shortest seminar I usually do is 50 hours.(Laughter)I'm not exaggerating. I do weekends — I do more, obviously, I also coach people — but I'm into immersion, because how did you learn language? Not just by learning principles, you got in it and you did it so often that it became real.The bottom line of why I'm here, besides being a crazy mofo, is that — I'm not here to motivate you, you don't need that, obviously. Often that's what people think I do, and it's the furthest thing from it. What happens, though, is people say to me, "I don't need any motivation." But that's not what I do. I'm the "why" guy. I want to know why you do what you do.What is your motive for action? What is it that drives you in your life today? Not 10 years ago. Are you running the same pattern? Because I believe that the invisible force of internal drive, activated, is the most important thing. I'm here because I believe emotion is the force of life. All of us here have great minds. Most of us here have great minds, right? We all know how to think. With our minds we can rationalize anything. We can make anything happen.I agree with what was described a few days ago, that people work in their self-interest. But we know that that's bullshit at times. You don't work in your self-interest all the time, because when emotion comes into it, the wiring changes in the way it functions. So it's wonderful to think intellectually about how the life of the world is, especially those who are very smart can play this game in our head. But I really want to know what's driving you.What I would like to invite you to do by the end of this talk is explore where you are today, for two reasons. One: so that you can contribute more. And two: that hopefully we can not just understand other people more, but appreciate them more, and create the kinds of connections that can stop some of the challenges that we face today. They're only going to get magnified by the very technology that connects us, because it's making us intersect. That intersection doesn't always create a view of "everybody now understands everybody, and everybody appreciates everybody."I've had an obsession basically for 30 years, "What makes the difference in the quality of people's lives? What in their performance?" I got hired to produce the result now. I've done it for 30 years. I get the phone call when the athlete is burning down on national television, and they were ahead by five strokes and now they can't get back on the course. I've got to do something right now or nothing matters. I get the phone call when the child is going to commit suicide, I've got to do something. In 29 years, I'm very grateful to tell you I've never lost one. It doesn't mean I won't some day, but I haven't yet. The reason is an understanding of these human needs.When I get those calls about performance, that's one thing. How do you make a change? I'm also looking to see what is shaping the person's ability to contribute, to do something beyond themselves. Maybe the real question is, I look at life and say there's two master lessons. One is: there's the science of achievement, which almost everyone here has mastered amazingly. "How do you take the invisible and make it visible," How do you make your dreams happen? Your business, your contribution to society, money — whatever, your body, your family.The other lesson that is rarely mastered is the art of fulfillment. Because science is easy, right? We know the rules, you write the code and you get the results. Once you know the game, you just up the ante, don't you? But when it comes to fulfillment — that's an art. The reason is, it's about appreciation and contribution. You can only feel so much by yourself.I've had an interesting laboratory to try to answer the real question how somebody's life changes if you look at them like those people that you've given everything to? Like all the resources they say they need. You gave not a 100-dollar computer, but the best computer. You gave them love, joy, were there to comfort them. Those people very often — you know some of them — end up the rest of their life with all this love, education, money and background going in and out of rehab. Some people have been through ultimate pain, psychologically, sexually, spiritually, emotionally abused — and not always, but often, they become some of the people that contribute the most to society.The question we've got to ask ourselves really is, what is it? What is it that shapes us? We live in a therapy culture. Most of us don't do that, but the culture's a therapy culture, the mindset that we are our past. And you wouldn't be in this room if you bought that, but most of society thinks biography is destiny. The past equals the future. Of course it does if you live there. But what we know and what we have to remind ourselves — because you can know something intellectually and then not use it, not apply it.We've got to remind ourselves that decision is the ultimate power. When you ask people, have you failed to achieve something significant in your life?Say, "Aye." Audience: Aye.TR: Thanks for the interaction on a high level there. But if you ask people, why didn't you achieve something? Somebody who's working for you, or a partner, or even yourself. When you fail to achieve, what's the reason people say? What do they tell you? Didn't have the knowledge, didn't have the money, didn't have the time, didn't have the technology. I didn't have the right manager.Al Gore: Supreme Court. TR: The Supreme Court.(Laughter)(Applause) (Cheering)(Applause continues)TR: And —(Applause)What do all those, including the Supreme Court, have in common?(Laughter)They are a claim to you missing resources, and they may be accurate. You may not have the money, or the Supreme Court, but that is not the defining factor.(Applause) (Laughter)And you correct me if I'm wrong. The defining factor is never resources; it's resourcefulness. And what I mean specifically, rather than just some phrase, is if you have emotion, human emotion, something that I experienced from you the day before yesterday at a level that is as profound as I've ever experienced and I believe with that emotion you would have beat his ass and won.Audience: Yeah!(Applause) (Cheering)How easy for me to tell him what he should do.(Laughter)Idiot, Robbins. But I know when we watched the debate at that time, there were emotions that blocked people's ability to get this man's intellect and capacity. And the way that it came across to some people on that day — because I know people that wanted to vote in your direction and didn't, and I was upset. But there was emotion there. Do you know what I'm talking about?Say, "Aye." Audience: Aye.TR: So, emotion is it. And if we get the right emotion, we can get ourselves to do anything. If you're creative, playful, fun enough, can you get through to anybody, yes or no?If you don't have the money, but you're creative and determined, you find the way. This is the ultimate resource. But this is not the story that people tell us. They tell us a bunch of different stories. They tell us we don't have the resources, but ultimately, if you take a look here, they say, what are all the reasons they haven't accomplished that? He's broken my pattern, that son-of-a-bitch.(Laughter)But I appreciated the energy, I'll tell you that.(Laughter)What determines your resources? We've said decisions shape destiny, which is my focus here. If decisions shape destiny, what determines it is three decisions. What will you focus on? You have to decide what you're going to focus on. Consciously or unconsciously. the minute you decide to focus, you must give it a meaning, and that meaning produces emotion. Is this the end or the beginning? Is God punishing me or rewarding me, or is this the roll of the dice? An emotion creates what we're going to do, or the action.So, think about your own life, the decisions that have shaped your destiny. And that sounds really heavy, but in the last five or 10 years, have there been some decisions that if you'd made a different decision, your life would be completely different? How many can think about it? Better or worse. Say, "Aye."Audience: Aye.So the bottom line is, maybe it was where to go to work, and you met the love of your life there, a career decision. I know the Google geniuses I saw here — I mean, I understand that their decision was to sell their technology. What if they made that decision versus to build their own culture? How would the world or their lives be different, their impact? The history of our world is these decisions. When a woman stands up and says, "No, I won't go to the back of the bus." She didn't just affect her life. That decision shaped our culture. Or someone standing in front of a tank. Or being in a position like Lance Armstrong, "You've got testicular cancer." That's pretty tough for any male, especially if you ride a bike.(Laughter)You've got it in your brain; you've got it in your lungs. But what was his decision of what to focus on? Different than most people. What did it mean? It wasn't the end; it was the beginning. He goes off and wins seven championships he never once won before the cancer, because he got emotional fitness, psychological strength. That's the difference in human beings that I've seen of the three million I've been around.In my lab, I've had three million people from 80 countries over the last 29 years. And after a while, patterns become obvious. You see that South America and Africa may be connected in a certain way, right? Others say, "Oh, that sounds ridiculous." It's simple. So, what shaped Lance? What shapes you? Two invisible forces. Very quickly. One: state. We all have had times, you did something, and after, you thought to yourself, "I can't believe I said or did that, that was so stupid." Who's been there? Say, "Aye." Audience: Aye.Or after you did something, you go, "That was me!"(Laughter)It wasn't your ability; it was your state. Your model of the world is what shapes you long term. Your model of the world is the filter. That's what's shaping us. It makes people make decisions. To influence somebody, we need to know what already influences them. It's made up of three parts. First, what's your target? What are you after? It's not your desires. You can get your desires or goals. Who has ever got a goal or desire and thought, is this all there is?Say, "Aye." Audience: Aye.It's needs we have. I believe there are six human needs. Second, once you know what the target that's driving you is and you uncover it for the truth — you don't form it — then you find out what's your map, what's the belief systems that tell you how to get those needs. Some people think the way to get them is to destroy the world, some people, to build, create something, love someone. There's the fuel you pick. So very quickly, six needs.Let me tell you what they are. First one: certainty. These are not goals or desires, these are universal. Everyone needs certainty they can avoid pain and at least be comfortable. Now, how do you get it? Control everybody? Develop a skill? Give up? Smoke a cigarette? And if you got totally certain, ironically, even though we need that — you're not certain about your health, or your children, or money. If you're not sure the ceiling will hold up, you won't listen to any speaker. While we go for certainty differently, if we get total certainty, we get what? What do you feel if you're certain? You know what will happen, when and how it will happen, what would you feel? Bored out of your minds. So, God, in Her infinite wisdom, gave us a second human need, which is uncertainty. We need variety. We need surprise. How many of you here love surprises? Say, "Aye."Audience: Aye.TR: Bullshit. You like the surprises you want. The ones you don't want, you call problems, but you need them. So, variety is important. Have you ever rented a video or a film that you've already seen? Who's done this? Get a fucking life.(Laughter)Why are you doing it? You're certain it's good because you read or saw it before, but you're hoping it's been long enough you've forgotten, and there's variety.Third human need, critical: significance. We all need to feel important, special, unique. You can get it by making more money or being more spiritual. You can do it by getting yourself in a situation where you put more tattoos and earrings in places humans don't want to know. Whatever it takes. The fastest way to do this, if you have no background, no culture, no belief and resources or resourcefulness, is violence. If I put a gun to your head and I live in the 'hood, instantly I'm significant. Zero to 10. How high? 10. How certain am I that you're going to respond to me? 10. How much uncertainty? Who knows what's going to happen next? Kind of exciting. Like climbing up into a cave and doing that stuff all the way down there. Total variety and uncertainty. And it's significant, isn't it? So you want to risk your life for it. So that's why violence has always been around and will be around unless we have a consciousness change as a species. You can get significance a million ways, but to be significant, you've got to be unique and different.Here's what we really need: connection and love, fourth need. We all want it; most settle for connection, love's too scary. Who here has been hurt in an intimate relationship? If you don't raise your hand, you've had other shit, too. And you're going to get hurt again. Aren't you glad you came to this positive visit? Here's what's true: we need it. We can do it through intimacy, friendship, prayer, through walking in nature. If nothing else works for you, don't get a cat, get a dog, because if you leave for two minutes, it's like you've been gone six months, when you come back 5 minutes later.These first four needs, every human finds a way to meet. Even if you lie to yourself, you need to have split personalities. I call the first four needs the needs of the personality. The last two are the needs of the spirit. And this is where fulfillment comes. You won't get it from the first four. You'll figure a way, smoke, drink, do whatever, meet the first four. But number five, you must grow. We all know the answer. If you don't grow, you're what? If a relationship or business is not growing, if you're not growing, doesn't matter how much money or friends you have, how many love you, you feel like hell. And I believe the reason we grow is so we have something to give of value.Because the sixth need is to contribute beyond ourselves. Because we all know, corny as that sounds, the secret to living is giving. We all know life is not about me, it's about we. This culture knows that, this room knows that. It's exciting. When you see Nicholas talking about his $100 computer, the most exciting thing is: here's a genius, but he's got a calling now. You can feel the difference in him, and it's beautiful. And that calling can touch other people.My life was touched because when I was 11 years old, Thanksgiving, no money, no food, we were not going to starve, but my father was totally messed up, my mom was letting him know how bad he messed up, and somebody came to the door and delivered food. My father made three decisions, I know what they were, briefly. His focus was "This is charity. What does it mean? I'm worthless. What do I have to do? Leave my family," which he did. It was one of the most painful experiences of life. My three decisions gave me a different path. I set focus on "There's food." What a concept!(Laughter)But this is what changed my life, shaped me as a human being. Somebody's gift, I don't even know who it is. My father always said, "No one gives a shit." And now somebody I don't know, they're not asking for anything, just giving us food, looking out for us. It made me believe this: that strangers care. And that made me decide, if strangers care about me and my family, I care about them. I'm going to do something to make a difference. So when I was 17, I went out on Thanksgiving, it was my target for years to have enough money to feed two families. The most fun and moving thing I ever did in my life. Next year, I did four, then eight. I didn't tell anybody what I was doing, I wasn't doing it for brownie points. But after eight, I thought I could use some help.So I went out, got my friends involved, then I grew companies, got 11, and I built the foundation. 18 years later, I'm proud to tell you last year we fed 2 million people in 35 countries through our foundation. All during the holidays, Thanksgiving, Christmas, in different countries around the world.(Applause)Thank you. I don't tell you that to brag, but because I'm proud of human beings because they get excited to contribute once they've had the chance to experience it, not talk about it.So, finally — I'm about out of time. The target that shapes you — Here's what's different about people. We have the same needs. But are you a certainty freak, is that what you value most, or uncertainty? This man couldn't be a certainty freak if he climbed through those caves. Are you driven by significance or love? We all need all six, but what your lead system is tilts you in a different direction. And as you move in a direction, you have a destination or destiny. The second piece is the map. The operating system tells you how to get there, and some people's map is, "I'm going to save lives even if I die for other people," and they're a fireman, and somebody else says, "I'm going to kill people to do it." They're trying to meet the same needs of significance. They want to honor God or honor their family. But they have a different map.And there are seven different beliefs; I can't go through them, because I'm done. The last piece is emotion. One of the parts of the map is like time. Some people's idea of a long time is 100 years. Somebody else's is three seconds, which is what I have. And the last one I've already mentioned that fell to you. If you've got a target and a map — I can't use Google because I love Macs, and they haven't made it good for Macs yet. So if you use MapQuest — how many have made this fatal mistake of using it? You use this thing and you don't get there. Imagine if your beliefs guarantee you can never get to where you want to go.(Laughter)The last thing is emotion. Here's what I'll tell you about emotion. There are 6,000 emotions that we have words for in the English language, which is just a linguistic representation that changes by language. But if your dominant emotions — If I have 20,000 people or 1,000 and I have them write down all the emotions that they experience in an average week, and I give them as long as they need, and on one side they write empowering emotions, the other's disempowering, guess how many emotions they experience? Less than 12. And half of those make them feel like shit. They have six good feelings. Happy, happy, excited, oh shit, frustrated, frustrated, overwhelmed, depressed. How many of you know somebody who, no matter what happens, finds a way to get pissed off?(Laughter)Or no matter what happens, they find a way to be happy or excited. How many of you know somebody like this?When 9/11 happened, I'll finish with this, I was in Hawaii. I was with 2,000 people from 45 countries, we were translating four languages simultaneously for a program I was conducting, for a week. The night before was called Emotional Mastery. I got up, had no plan for this, and I said — we had fireworks, I do crazy shit, fun stuff, and at the end, I stopped. I had this plan, but I never know what I'm going to say. And all of a sudden, I said, "When do people really start to live? When they face death." And I went through this whole thing about, if you weren't going to get off this island, if nine days from now, you were going to die, who would you call, what would you say, what would you do? That night is when 9/11 happened.One woman had come to the seminar, and when she came there, her previous boyfriend had been kidnapped and murdered. Her new boyfriend wanted to marry her, and she said no.He said, "If you go to that Hawaii thing, it's over with us." She said, "It's over." When I finished that night, she called him and left a message at the top of the World Trade Center where he worked, saying, "I love you, I want you to know I want to marry you. It was stupid of me." She was asleep, because it was 3 a.m. for us, when he called her back, and said, "Honey, I can't tell you what this means. I don't know how to tell you this, but you gave me the greatest gift, because I'm going to die." And she played the recording for us in the room. She was on Larry King later. And he said, "You're probably wondering how on Earth this could happen to you twice. All I can say is this must be God's message to you. From now on, every day, give your all, love your all. Don't let anything ever stop you." She finishes, and a man stands up, and he says, "I'm from Pakistan, I'm a Muslim. I'd love to hold your hand and say I'm sorry, but frankly, this is retribution." I can't tell you the rest, because I'm out of time.(Laughter)Are you sure?(Laughter)10 seconds!(Laughter and applause)10 seconds, I want to be respectful. All I can tell you is, I brought this man on stage with a man from New York who worked in the World Trade Center, because I had about 200 New Yorkers there. More than 50 lost their entire companies, friends, marking off their Palm Pilots. One financial trader, woman made of steel, bawling — 30 friends crossing off that all died. And I said, "What are we going to focus on? What does this mean and what are we going to do?"And I got the group to focus on: if you didn't lose somebody today, your focus is going to be how to serve somebody else. Then one woman stood up and was so angry, screaming and yelling. I found out she wasn't from New York, she's not an American, doesn't know anybody here. I asked, "Do you always get angry?" She said, "Yes." Guilty people got guilty, sad people got sad. I took these two men and I did an indirect negotiation. Jewish man with family in the occupied territory, someone in New York who would have died if he was at work that day, and this man who wanted to be a terrorist, and I made it very clear. This integration is on a film, which I'd be happy to send you, instead of my verbalization, but the two of them not only came together and changed their beliefs and models of the world, but worked together to bring, for almost four years now, through various mosques and synagogues, the idea of how to create peace. And he wrote a book, called "My Jihad, My Way of Peace." So, transformation can happen.My invitation to you is: explore your web, the web in here — the needs, the beliefs, the emotions that are controlling you, for two reasons: so there's more of you to give, and achieve, too, but I mean give, because that's what's going to fill you up. And secondly, so you can appreciate — not just understand, that's intellectual, that's the mind, but appreciate what's driving other people. It's the only way our world's going to change.God bless you, thank you. I hope this was of service.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:13.958 --> 00:00:17.436
Thank you. I have to tell you
I'm both challenged and excited.

00:00:17.460 --> 00:00:20.372
My excitement is: I get a chance
to give something back.

00:00:20.396 --> 00:00:23.934
My challenge is: the shortest seminar
I usually do is 50 hours.

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:25.583
(Laughter)

00:00:25.607 --> 00:00:27.837
I'm not exaggerating. I do weekends --

00:00:27.861 --> 00:00:30.096
I do more, obviously,
I also coach people --

00:00:30.120 --> 00:00:32.891
but I'm into immersion,
because how did you learn language?

00:00:32.915 --> 00:00:34.520
Not just by learning principles,

00:00:34.544 --> 00:00:37.397
you got in it and you did it
so often that it became real.

00:00:37.421 --> 00:00:40.898
The bottom line of why I'm here,
besides being a crazy mofo, is that --

00:00:40.922 --> 00:00:44.661
I'm not here to motivate you,
you don't need that, obviously.

00:00:44.685 --> 00:00:46.708
Often that's what people think I do,

00:00:46.732 --> 00:00:48.447
and it's the furthest thing from it.

00:00:48.471 --> 00:00:50.516
What happens, though, is people say to me,

00:00:50.540 --> 00:00:52.008
"I don't need any motivation."

00:00:52.033 --> 00:00:53.575
But that's not what I do.

00:00:53.599 --> 00:00:55.466
I'm the "why" guy.

00:00:55.490 --> 00:00:57.562
I want to know why you do what you do.

00:00:57.586 --> 00:00:59.411
What is your motive for action?

00:01:00.093 --> 00:01:03.271
What is it that drives you
in your life today? Not 10 years ago.

00:01:03.295 --> 00:01:05.000
Are you running the same pattern?

00:01:05.024 --> 00:01:08.936
Because I believe that the invisible force
of internal drive, activated,

00:01:08.960 --> 00:01:10.768
is the most important thing.

00:01:10.792 --> 00:01:14.371
I'm here because I believe
emotion is the force of life.

00:01:14.395 --> 00:01:16.212
All of us here have great minds.

00:01:16.236 --> 00:01:18.664
Most of us here have great minds, right?

00:01:18.688 --> 00:01:21.048
We all know how to think.

00:01:21.072 --> 00:01:23.161
With our minds we can
rationalize anything.

00:01:23.185 --> 00:01:24.527
We can make anything happen.

00:01:24.551 --> 00:01:27.329
I agree with what was described
a few days ago,

00:01:27.353 --> 00:01:29.680
that people work in their self-interest.

00:01:29.704 --> 00:01:32.322
But we know that that's bullshit at times.

00:01:32.346 --> 00:01:34.710
You don't work in your
self-interest all the time,

00:01:34.734 --> 00:01:36.601
because when emotion comes into it,

00:01:36.625 --> 00:01:38.668
the wiring changes
in the way it functions.

00:01:38.692 --> 00:01:42.643
So it's wonderful to think intellectually
about how the life of the world is,

00:01:42.667 --> 00:01:45.826
especially those who are very smart
can play this game in our head.

00:01:45.850 --> 00:01:47.952
But I really want to know
what's driving you.

00:01:47.976 --> 00:01:49.834
What I would like to invite you to do

00:01:49.858 --> 00:01:53.364
by the end of this talk is explore
where you are today, for two reasons.

00:01:53.388 --> 00:01:55.269
One: so that you can contribute more.

00:01:55.293 --> 00:01:58.563
And two: that hopefully we can not just
understand other people more,

00:01:58.587 --> 00:02:01.477
but appreciate them more,
and create the kinds of connections

00:02:01.501 --> 00:02:04.424
that can stop some of the challenges
that we face today.

00:02:04.448 --> 00:02:08.193
They're only going to get magnified
by the very technology that connects us,

00:02:08.217 --> 00:02:10.003
because it's making us intersect.

00:02:10.027 --> 00:02:12.253
That intersection
doesn't always create a view

00:02:12.277 --> 00:02:14.463
of "everybody now understands everybody,

00:02:14.487 --> 00:02:16.851
and everybody appreciates everybody."

00:02:16.875 --> 00:02:19.466
I've had an obsession
basically for 30 years,

00:02:19.490 --> 00:02:23.805
"What makes the difference
in the quality of people's lives?

00:02:23.829 --> 00:02:25.286
What in their performance?"

00:02:25.310 --> 00:02:27.488
I got hired to produce the result now.

00:02:27.512 --> 00:02:29.008
I've done it for 30 years.

00:02:29.032 --> 00:02:30.579
I get the phone call

00:02:30.603 --> 00:02:33.345
when the athlete is burning down
on national television,

00:02:33.369 --> 00:02:35.055
and they were ahead by five strokes

00:02:35.079 --> 00:02:37.079
and now they can't get back on the course.

00:02:37.103 --> 00:02:39.789
I've got to do something right now
or nothing matters.

00:02:39.813 --> 00:02:42.785
I get the phone call when the child
is going to commit suicide,

00:02:42.809 --> 00:02:44.256
I've got to do something.

00:02:44.280 --> 00:02:47.934
In 29 years, I'm very grateful
to tell you I've never lost one.

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:50.462
It doesn't mean I won't some day,
but I haven't yet.

00:02:50.486 --> 00:02:53.862
The reason is an understanding
of these human needs.

00:02:53.886 --> 00:02:56.997
When I get those calls
about performance, that's one thing.

00:02:57.021 --> 00:02:58.507
How do you make a change?

00:02:58.531 --> 00:03:02.526
I'm also looking to see what is shaping
the person's ability to contribute,

00:03:02.550 --> 00:03:06.060
to do something beyond themselves.

00:03:06.084 --> 00:03:08.192
Maybe the real question is,

00:03:08.216 --> 00:03:10.587
I look at life and say
there's two master lessons.

00:03:10.611 --> 00:03:12.690
One is: there's the science
of achievement,

00:03:12.714 --> 00:03:15.484
which almost everyone here
has mastered amazingly.

00:03:15.508 --> 00:03:18.003
"How do you take the invisible
and make it visible,"

00:03:18.027 --> 00:03:19.744
How do you make your dreams happen?

00:03:19.768 --> 00:03:22.355
Your business, your contribution
to society, money --

00:03:22.379 --> 00:03:24.091
whatever, your body, your family.

00:03:24.115 --> 00:03:27.618
The other lesson that is rarely
mastered is the art of fulfillment.

00:03:28.475 --> 00:03:30.051
Because science is easy, right?

00:03:30.075 --> 00:03:32.980
We know the rules, you write the code
and you get the results.

00:03:33.004 --> 00:03:36.148
Once you know the game,
you just up the ante, don't you?

00:03:36.172 --> 00:03:38.605
But when it comes
to fulfillment -- that's an art.

00:03:38.629 --> 00:03:41.825
The reason is, it's about
appreciation and contribution.

00:03:41.849 --> 00:03:43.934
You can only feel so much by yourself.

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:47.894
I've had an interesting laboratory
to try to answer the real question

00:03:47.918 --> 00:03:49.474
how somebody's life changes

00:03:49.498 --> 00:03:52.809
if you look at them like those people
that you've given everything to?

00:03:52.833 --> 00:03:54.957
Like all the resources they say they need.

00:03:54.981 --> 00:03:57.767
You gave not a 100-dollar computer,
but the best computer.

00:03:57.791 --> 00:04:00.313
You gave them love, joy,
were there to comfort them.

00:04:00.337 --> 00:04:02.933
Those people very often --
you know some of them --

00:04:02.957 --> 00:04:04.398
end up the rest of their life

00:04:04.422 --> 00:04:06.847
with all this love, education,
money and background

00:04:06.871 --> 00:04:08.255
going in and out of rehab.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:11.934
Some people have been
through ultimate pain,

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:15.333
psychologically, sexually,
spiritually, emotionally abused --

00:04:15.357 --> 00:04:17.013
and not always, but often,

00:04:17.037 --> 00:04:20.241
they become some of the people
that contribute the most to society.

00:04:20.265 --> 00:04:24.197
The question we've got to ask
ourselves really is, what is it?

00:04:24.221 --> 00:04:25.564
What is it that shapes us?

00:04:25.588 --> 00:04:27.199
We live in a therapy culture.

00:04:27.223 --> 00:04:30.265
Most of us don't do that,
but the culture's a therapy culture,

00:04:30.289 --> 00:04:32.278
the mindset that we are our past.

00:04:32.302 --> 00:04:34.934
And you wouldn't be in this room
if you bought that,

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:38.136
but most of society
thinks biography is destiny.

00:04:38.160 --> 00:04:39.803
The past equals the future.

00:04:39.827 --> 00:04:41.542
Of course it does if you live there.

00:04:41.566 --> 00:04:44.234
But what we know and what
we have to remind ourselves --

00:04:44.258 --> 00:04:46.452
because you can know
something intellectually

00:04:46.476 --> 00:04:48.324
and then not use it, not apply it.

00:04:48.878 --> 00:04:52.586
We've got to remind ourselves
that decision is the ultimate power.

00:04:52.610 --> 00:04:55.314
When you ask people,

00:04:55.338 --> 00:04:59.211
have you failed to achieve
something significant in your life?

00:04:59.235 --> 00:05:00.934
Say, "Aye." Audience: Aye.

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:03.934
TR: Thanks for the interaction
on a high level there.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:06.934
But if you ask people,
why didn't you achieve something?

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:10.213
Somebody who's working for you,
or a partner, or even yourself.

00:05:10.237 --> 00:05:13.333
When you fail to achieve,
what's the reason people say?

00:05:13.357 --> 00:05:14.500
What do they tell you?

00:05:14.524 --> 00:05:18.833
Didn't have the knowledge,
didn't have the money,

00:05:18.857 --> 00:05:23.094
didn't have the time,
didn't have the technology.

00:05:23.118 --> 00:05:24.952
I didn't have the right manager.

00:05:24.976 --> 00:05:27.665
Al Gore: Supreme Court.
TR: The Supreme Court.

00:05:27.689 --> 00:05:29.919
(Laughter)

00:05:29.943 --> 00:05:32.491
(Applause) (Cheering)

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.934
(Applause continues)

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:45.013
TR: And --

00:05:45.037 --> 00:05:47.935
(Applause)

00:05:47.959 --> 00:05:51.055
What do all those, including
the Supreme Court, have in common?

00:05:51.079 --> 00:05:52.453
(Laughter)

00:05:52.477 --> 00:05:57.277
They are a claim to you missing
resources, and they may be accurate.

00:05:57.301 --> 00:05:59.934
You may not have the money,
or the Supreme Court,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.934
but that is not the defining factor.

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:07.915
(Applause) (Laughter)

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.482
And you correct me if I'm wrong.

00:06:10.672 --> 00:06:13.934
The defining factor is never resources;
it's resourcefulness.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:16.762
And what I mean specifically,
rather than just some phrase,

00:06:16.786 --> 00:06:19.998
is if you have emotion, human emotion,

00:06:20.022 --> 00:06:24.051
something that I experienced from you
the day before yesterday

00:06:24.075 --> 00:06:26.666
at a level that is as profound
as I've ever experienced

00:06:26.690 --> 00:06:29.928
and I believe with that emotion
you would have beat his ass and won.

00:06:29.952 --> 00:06:31.009
Audience: Yeah!

00:06:31.033 --> 00:06:35.700
(Applause) (Cheering)

00:06:35.724 --> 00:06:37.934
How easy for me to tell him
what he should do.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.934
(Laughter)

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.845
Idiot, Robbins.

00:06:42.869 --> 00:06:48.125
But I know when we watched
the debate at that time,

00:06:48.149 --> 00:06:50.436
there were emotions
that blocked people's ability

00:06:50.460 --> 00:06:52.437
to get this man's intellect and capacity.

00:06:52.461 --> 00:06:55.357
And the way that it came across
to some people on that day --

00:06:55.381 --> 00:06:58.756
because I know people that wanted
to vote in your direction and didn't,

00:06:58.780 --> 00:07:00.123
and I was upset.

00:07:00.147 --> 00:07:01.586
But there was emotion there.

00:07:01.610 --> 00:07:03.315
Do you know what I'm talking about?

00:07:03.339 --> 00:07:04.673
Say, "Aye." Audience: Aye.

00:07:04.697 --> 00:07:05.837
TR: So, emotion is it.

00:07:05.861 --> 00:07:09.611
And if we get the right emotion,
we can get ourselves to do anything.

00:07:09.635 --> 00:07:11.555
If you're creative, playful, fun enough,

00:07:11.579 --> 00:07:13.649
can you get through to anybody, yes or no?

00:07:13.673 --> 00:07:15.117
If you don't have the money,

00:07:15.141 --> 00:07:17.670
but you're creative and determined,
you find the way.

00:07:17.694 --> 00:07:19.177
This is the ultimate resource.

00:07:19.201 --> 00:07:21.434
But this is not the story
that people tell us.

00:07:21.458 --> 00:07:23.534
They tell us a bunch of different stories.

00:07:23.558 --> 00:07:26.267
They tell us we don't have
the resources, but ultimately,

00:07:26.291 --> 00:07:27.855
if you take a look here,

00:07:27.879 --> 00:07:31.221
they say, what are all the reasons
they haven't accomplished that?

00:07:31.245 --> 00:07:33.506
He's broken my pattern,
that son-of-a-bitch.

00:07:33.530 --> 00:07:36.857
(Laughter)

00:07:36.881 --> 00:07:39.235
But I appreciated the energy,
I'll tell you that.

00:07:39.259 --> 00:07:40.336
(Laughter)

00:07:40.360 --> 00:07:41.877
What determines your resources?

00:07:41.901 --> 00:07:45.038
We've said decisions shape destiny,
which is my focus here.

00:07:45.062 --> 00:07:48.158
If decisions shape destiny,
what determines it is three decisions.

00:07:48.182 --> 00:07:49.335
What will you focus on?

00:07:49.359 --> 00:07:51.810
You have to decide
what you're going to focus on.

00:07:51.834 --> 00:07:53.295
Consciously or unconsciously.

00:07:53.319 --> 00:07:56.230
the minute you decide to focus,
you must give it a meaning,

00:07:56.254 --> 00:07:58.143
and that meaning produces emotion.

00:07:58.167 --> 00:07:59.993
Is this the end or the beginning?

00:08:00.017 --> 00:08:03.916
Is God punishing me or rewarding me,
or is this the roll of the dice?

00:08:03.940 --> 00:08:06.934
An emotion creates
what we're going to do, or the action.

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.934
So, think about your own life,

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.006
the decisions that
have shaped your destiny.

00:08:11.030 --> 00:08:14.016
And that sounds really heavy,
but in the last five or 10 years,

00:08:14.040 --> 00:08:15.587
have there been some decisions

00:08:15.611 --> 00:08:19.448
that if you'd made a different decision,
your life would be completely different?

00:08:19.472 --> 00:08:22.166
How many can think about it?
Better or worse. Say, "Aye."

00:08:22.190 --> 00:08:23.222
Audience: Aye.

00:08:23.246 --> 00:08:25.910
So the bottom line is,
maybe it was where to go to work,

00:08:25.934 --> 00:08:28.787
and you met the love of your life there,
a career decision.

00:08:28.811 --> 00:08:30.777
I know the Google geniuses I saw here --

00:08:30.801 --> 00:08:34.189
I mean, I understand that their decision
was to sell their technology.

00:08:34.213 --> 00:08:37.354
What if they made that decision
versus to build their own culture?

00:08:37.378 --> 00:08:40.307
How would the world or their lives
be different, their impact?

00:08:40.331 --> 00:08:42.448
The history of our world
is these decisions.

00:08:42.472 --> 00:08:46.034
When a woman stands up and says,
"No, I won't go to the back of the bus."

00:08:46.058 --> 00:08:49.577
She didn't just affect her life.
That decision shaped our culture.

00:08:49.601 --> 00:08:52.120
Or someone standing in front of a tank.

00:08:52.144 --> 00:08:54.934
Or being in a position
like Lance Armstrong,

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.502
"You've got testicular cancer."

00:08:56.526 --> 00:08:59.565
That's pretty tough for any male,
especially if you ride a bike.

00:08:59.589 --> 00:09:00.934
(Laughter)

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.667
You've got it in your brain;
you've got it in your lungs.

00:09:03.691 --> 00:09:05.883
But what was his decision
of what to focus on?

00:09:05.907 --> 00:09:08.046
Different than most people.
What did it mean?

00:09:08.070 --> 00:09:10.021
It wasn't the end; it was the beginning.

00:09:10.045 --> 00:09:12.836
He goes off and wins
seven championships he never once won

00:09:12.860 --> 00:09:16.742
before the cancer, because he got
emotional fitness, psychological strength.

00:09:16.766 --> 00:09:19.257
That's the difference
in human beings that I've seen

00:09:19.281 --> 00:09:21.140
of the three million I've been around.

00:09:21.164 --> 00:09:26.949
In my lab, I've had three million people
from 80 countries over the last 29 years.

00:09:26.973 --> 00:09:29.437
And after a while,
patterns become obvious.

00:09:29.461 --> 00:09:33.460
You see that South America and Africa
may be connected in a certain way, right?

00:09:33.484 --> 00:09:36.102
Others say, "Oh, that sounds
ridiculous." It's simple.

00:09:36.126 --> 00:09:38.410
So, what shaped Lance? What shapes you?

00:09:38.434 --> 00:09:42.756
Two invisible forces.
Very quickly. One: state.

00:09:42.780 --> 00:09:43.934
We all have had times,

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.751
you did something, and after,
you thought to yourself,

00:09:46.775 --> 00:09:49.934
"I can't believe I said or did that,
that was so stupid."

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.053
Who's been there? Say, "Aye."
Audience: Aye.

00:09:52.077 --> 00:09:54.473
Or after you did something,
you go, "That was me!"

00:09:54.497 --> 00:09:55.934
(Laughter)

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:58.792
It wasn't your ability; it was your state.

00:09:58.816 --> 00:10:01.736
Your model of the world
is what shapes you long term.

00:10:01.760 --> 00:10:05.292
Your model of the world is the filter.
That's what's shaping us.

00:10:05.316 --> 00:10:06.916
It makes people make decisions.

00:10:06.940 --> 00:10:10.196
To influence somebody, we need to know
what already influences them.

00:10:10.220 --> 00:10:12.029
It's made up of three parts.

00:10:12.053 --> 00:10:14.392
First, what's your target?
What are you after?

00:10:14.416 --> 00:10:15.934
It's not your desires.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.593
You can get your desires or goals.

00:10:17.617 --> 00:10:20.831
Who has ever got a goal or desire
and thought, is this all there is?

00:10:20.855 --> 00:10:22.108
Say, "Aye." Audience: Aye.

00:10:22.132 --> 00:10:25.000
It's needs we have. I believe
there are six human needs.

00:10:25.024 --> 00:10:27.934
Second, once you know what the target
that's driving you is

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.934
and you uncover it for the truth --
you don't form it --

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.693
then you find out what's your map,

00:10:32.717 --> 00:10:35.778
what's the belief systems
that tell you how to get those needs.

00:10:35.802 --> 00:10:38.753
Some people think the way
to get them is to destroy the world,

00:10:38.777 --> 00:10:41.327
some people, to build,
create something, love someone.

00:10:41.351 --> 00:10:43.934
There's the fuel you pick.
So very quickly, six needs.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.429
Let me tell you what they are.
First one: certainty.

00:10:46.453 --> 00:10:48.916
These are not goals or desires,
these are universal.

00:10:48.940 --> 00:10:51.040
Everyone needs certainty
they can avoid pain

00:10:51.064 --> 00:10:52.481
and at least be comfortable.

00:10:52.505 --> 00:10:53.759
Now, how do you get it?

00:10:53.783 --> 00:10:56.868
Control everybody? Develop a skill?
Give up? Smoke a cigarette?

00:10:56.892 --> 00:10:58.934
And if you got totally
certain, ironically,

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.244
even though we need that --

00:11:00.268 --> 00:11:03.461
you're not certain about your health,
or your children, or money.

00:11:03.485 --> 00:11:05.700
If you're not sure
the ceiling will hold up,

00:11:05.724 --> 00:11:07.343
you won't listen to any speaker.

00:11:07.367 --> 00:11:11.116
While we go for certainty differently,
if we get total certainty, we get what?

00:11:11.140 --> 00:11:12.834
What do you feel if you're certain?

00:11:12.858 --> 00:11:15.511
You know what will happen,
when and how it will happen,

00:11:15.535 --> 00:11:16.634
what would you feel?

00:11:16.658 --> 00:11:19.334
Bored out of your minds.
So, God, in Her infinite wisdom,

00:11:19.358 --> 00:11:21.934
gave us a second human need,
which is uncertainty.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.934
We need variety. We need surprise.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.254
How many of you here
love surprises? Say, "Aye."

00:11:27.278 --> 00:11:28.359
Audience: Aye.

00:11:28.383 --> 00:11:30.994
TR: Bullshit. You like
the surprises you want.

00:11:31.018 --> 00:11:34.362
The ones you don't want,
you call problems, but you need them.

00:11:34.386 --> 00:11:36.165
So, variety is important.

00:11:36.189 --> 00:11:39.301
Have you ever rented a video
or a film that you've already seen?

00:11:39.325 --> 00:11:41.134
Who's done this? Get a fucking life.

00:11:41.158 --> 00:11:42.934
(Laughter)

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.568
Why are you doing it?

00:11:44.592 --> 00:11:47.375
You're certain it's good
because you read or saw it before,

00:11:47.399 --> 00:11:50.093
but you're hoping it's been
long enough you've forgotten,

00:11:50.117 --> 00:11:51.134
and there's variety.

00:11:51.158 --> 00:11:53.194
Third human need, critical: significance.

00:11:53.218 --> 00:11:55.493
We all need to feel important,
special, unique.

00:11:55.517 --> 00:11:58.384
You can get it by making more money
or being more spiritual.

00:11:58.408 --> 00:12:01.324
You can do it by getting yourself
in a situation where you put

00:12:01.348 --> 00:12:04.334
more tattoos and earrings in places
humans don't want to know.

00:12:04.358 --> 00:12:05.423
Whatever it takes.

00:12:05.447 --> 00:12:06.734
The fastest way to do this,

00:12:06.758 --> 00:12:09.734
if you have no background,
no culture, no belief and resources

00:12:09.758 --> 00:12:11.397
or resourcefulness, is violence.

00:12:11.421 --> 00:12:15.181
If I put a gun to your head and I live
in the 'hood, instantly I'm significant.

00:12:15.205 --> 00:12:16.666
Zero to 10. How high? 10.

00:12:16.690 --> 00:12:19.776
How certain am I that
you're going to respond to me? 10.

00:12:19.800 --> 00:12:20.916
How much uncertainty?

00:12:20.940 --> 00:12:23.634
Who knows what's going to happen next?
