00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.854
I've been at MIT for 44 years.

00:00:14.878 --> 00:00:16.814
I went to TED I.

00:00:16.838 --> 00:00:19.694
There's only one other person here,
I think, who did that.

00:00:19.718 --> 00:00:20.934
All the other TEDs --

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:23.214
and I went to them all,
under Ricky's regime --

00:00:23.238 --> 00:00:25.774
I talked about
what the Media Lab was doing,

00:00:25.798 --> 00:00:28.814
which today has almost 500 people in it.

00:00:28.838 --> 00:00:30.254
And if you read the press,

00:00:30.278 --> 00:00:32.934
last week it actually said
I quit the Media Lab.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:37.134
I didn't quit the Media Lab,
I stepped down as chairman --

00:00:37.158 --> 00:00:41.854
which was a kind of ridiculous title,
but someone else has taken it on --

00:00:41.878 --> 00:00:44.069
and one of the things
you can do as a professor

00:00:44.093 --> 00:00:45.934
is you stay on as a professor.

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:50.214
And I will now do for the rest of my life
the One Laptop Per Child,

00:00:50.238 --> 00:00:53.254
which I've sort of been doing
for a year and a half, anyway.

00:00:53.278 --> 00:00:55.014
So I'm going to tell you about this,

00:00:55.038 --> 00:00:59.134
use my 18 minutes
to tell you why we're doing it,

00:00:59.158 --> 00:01:01.334
how we're doing it
and then what we're doing.

00:01:01.358 --> 00:01:04.654
And at some point I'll even pass around

00:01:04.678 --> 00:01:08.598
what the $100 laptop might be like.

00:01:10.758 --> 00:01:13.614
I was asked by Chris
to talk about some of the big issues,

00:01:13.638 --> 00:01:18.894
and so I figured I'd start with the three
that at least drove me to do this.

00:01:18.918 --> 00:01:21.734
And the first is pretty obvious.

00:01:21.758 --> 00:01:24.414
It's amazing when you meet
a head of state, and you say,

00:01:24.438 --> 00:01:27.174
"What is your most precious
natural resource?"

00:01:27.198 --> 00:01:29.894
They will not say "children" at first,

00:01:29.918 --> 00:01:34.173
and then when you say, "children,"
they will pretty quickly agree with you.

00:01:34.197 --> 00:01:36.214
And so that isn't very hard.

00:01:36.238 --> 00:01:38.934
(Laughter)

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:44.014
Everybody agrees that whatever
the solutions are to the big problems,

00:01:44.038 --> 00:01:48.774
they include education,
sometimes can be just education

00:01:48.798 --> 00:01:52.094
and can never be without
some element of education.

00:01:52.118 --> 00:01:53.934
So that's certainly part of it.

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:56.334
And the third
is a little bit less obvious.

00:01:56.358 --> 00:02:01.094
And that is that we all in this room
learned how to walk, how to talk,

00:02:01.118 --> 00:02:05.614
not by being taught how to talk,
or taught how to walk,

00:02:05.638 --> 00:02:07.334
but by interacting with the world,

00:02:07.358 --> 00:02:11.494
by having certain results as a consequence
of being able to ask for something,

00:02:11.518 --> 00:02:13.654
or being able to stand up and reach it.

00:02:13.678 --> 00:02:17.934
Whereas at about the age six,
we were told to stop learning that way,

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:21.294
and that all learning from then on
would happen through teaching,

00:02:21.318 --> 00:02:23.747
whether it's people standing up,
like I'm doing now,

00:02:23.771 --> 00:02:25.494
or a book, or something.

00:02:25.518 --> 00:02:27.454
But it was really through teaching.

00:02:27.478 --> 00:02:32.654
And one of the things in general
that computers have provided to learning

00:02:32.678 --> 00:02:35.814
is that it now includes a kind of learning

00:02:35.838 --> 00:02:38.934
which is a little bit more
like walking and talking,

00:02:38.958 --> 00:02:45.574
in the sense that a lot of it is driven
by the learner himself or herself.

00:02:45.598 --> 00:02:48.334
So with those as the principles --

00:02:48.358 --> 00:02:50.374
some of you may know Seymour Papert.

00:02:50.398 --> 00:02:53.934
This is back in 1982,
when we were working in Senegal.

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:59.203
Because some people think that
the $100 laptop just happened a year ago,

00:02:59.227 --> 00:03:02.414
or two years ago,
or we were struck by lightning --

00:03:02.438 --> 00:03:07.494
this actually has gone back a long time,
and in fact, back to the '60s.

00:03:07.518 --> 00:03:09.054
Here we're in the '80s.

00:03:09.078 --> 00:03:13.334
Steve Jobs had given us some laptops.
We were in Senegal.

00:03:13.358 --> 00:03:14.614
It didn't scale

00:03:14.638 --> 00:03:19.734
but it at least was bringing computers
to developing countries

00:03:19.758 --> 00:03:22.214
and learning pretty quickly
that these kids,

00:03:22.238 --> 00:03:24.238
even though English wasn't their language,

00:03:24.262 --> 00:03:27.494
the Latin alphabet
barely was their language,

00:03:27.518 --> 00:03:29.854
but they could just swim like fish.

00:03:29.878 --> 00:03:31.638
They could play these like pianos.

00:03:33.318 --> 00:03:37.534
A little bit more recently,
I got involved personally.

00:03:37.558 --> 00:03:39.294
And these are two anecdotes --

00:03:39.318 --> 00:03:41.934
one was in Cambodia,

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:46.374
in a village that has no electricity,
no water, no television, no telephone,

00:03:46.398 --> 00:03:48.534
but has broadband Internet now.

00:03:48.558 --> 00:03:52.054
And these kids,
their first English word is "Google"

00:03:52.078 --> 00:03:54.414
and they only know Skype.

00:03:54.438 --> 00:03:56.054
They've never heard of telephony.

00:03:56.078 --> 00:03:58.214
They just use Skype.

00:03:58.238 --> 00:04:00.094
And they go home at night --

00:04:00.118 --> 00:04:03.934
they've got a broadband connection
in a hut that doesn't have electricity.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:06.720
The parents love it,
because when they open up the laptops,

00:04:06.744 --> 00:04:08.934
it's the brightest light source
in the house.

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:12.334
And talk about
where metaphors and reality mix --

00:04:12.358 --> 00:04:14.958
this is the actual school.

00:04:15.518 --> 00:04:20.614
In parallel with this,
Seymour Papert got the governor of Maine

00:04:20.638 --> 00:04:26.134
to legislate one laptop per child
in the year 2002.

00:04:26.158 --> 00:04:31.254
Now at the time, I think it's fair to say
that 80 percent of the teachers were --

00:04:31.278 --> 00:04:32.854
let me say, apprehensive.

00:04:32.878 --> 00:04:34.694
Really, they were actually against it.

00:04:34.718 --> 00:04:37.242
And they really preferred
that the money would be used

00:04:37.266 --> 00:04:39.654
for higher salaries,
more schools, whatever.

00:04:39.678 --> 00:04:43.934
And now, three and a half
years later, guess what?

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:50.174
They're reporting five things:
drop of truancy to almost zero,

00:04:50.198 --> 00:04:52.123
attending parent-teacher meetings --

00:04:52.147 --> 00:04:54.654
which nobody did
and now almost everybody does --

00:04:54.678 --> 00:04:58.574
drop in discipline problems,
increase in student participation.

00:04:58.598 --> 00:05:01.014
Teachers are now saying
it's kind of fun to teach.

00:05:01.038 --> 00:05:04.174
Kids are engaged -- they have laptops! --

00:05:04.198 --> 00:05:06.654
and then the fifth,
which interests me the most,

00:05:06.678 --> 00:05:09.894
is that the servers have to be turned off
at certain times at night

00:05:09.918 --> 00:05:12.334
because the teachers
are getting too much email

00:05:12.358 --> 00:05:14.334
from the kids asking them for help.

00:05:14.358 --> 00:05:16.134
So when you see that kind of thing --

00:05:16.158 --> 00:05:18.206
this is not something
that you have to test.

00:05:18.230 --> 00:05:20.934
The days of pilot projects are over,
when people say,

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:25.014
"We'd like to do three or four thousand
in our country to see how it works."

00:05:25.038 --> 00:05:28.134
Screw you. Go to the back of the line
and someone else will do it,

00:05:28.158 --> 00:05:32.694
and then when you figure out
that this works, you can join as well.

00:05:32.718 --> 00:05:35.294
And this is what we're doing.

00:05:35.318 --> 00:05:37.454
(Laughter) (Applause)

00:05:37.478 --> 00:05:42.454
So, One Laptop Per Child
was formed about a year and a half ago.

00:05:42.478 --> 00:05:44.374
It's a nonprofit association.

00:05:44.398 --> 00:05:46.334
It raised about 20 million dollars

00:05:46.358 --> 00:05:50.174
to do the engineering
to just get this built,

00:05:50.198 --> 00:05:52.854
and then have it produced afterwards.

00:05:52.878 --> 00:05:55.134
Scale is truly important.

00:05:55.158 --> 00:06:01.454
And it's not important because you can
buy components at a lower price, OK?

00:06:01.478 --> 00:06:04.354
It's because you can go
to a manufacturer --

00:06:04.378 --> 00:06:06.020
and I will leave the name out --

00:06:06.044 --> 00:06:09.574
but we wanted a small display,

00:06:09.598 --> 00:06:13.374
doesn't have to have
perfect color uniformity.

00:06:13.398 --> 00:06:15.760
It can even have a pixel or two missing.

00:06:15.784 --> 00:06:18.334
It doesn't have to be that bright.

00:06:18.358 --> 00:06:20.654
And this particular manufacturer said,

00:06:20.678 --> 00:06:23.821
"We're not interested in that.
We're interested in the living room.

00:06:23.845 --> 00:06:26.014
We're interested
in perfect color uniformity.

00:06:26.038 --> 00:06:28.374
We're interested in big displays,
bright displays.

00:06:28.398 --> 00:06:31.174
You're not part of our strategic plan."

00:06:31.198 --> 00:06:34.913
And I said, "That's kind of too bad,
because we need 100 million units a year."

00:06:34.937 --> 00:06:36.508
(Laughter)

00:06:36.532 --> 00:06:40.494
And they said, "Oh, well, maybe we could
become part of your strategic plan."

00:06:40.518 --> 00:06:42.934
And that's why scale counts.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:45.214
And that's why we will not launch this

00:06:45.238 --> 00:06:49.134
without five to 10 million units
in the first run.

00:06:49.158 --> 00:06:52.134
And the idea is
to launch with enough scale

00:06:52.158 --> 00:06:54.734
that the scale itself
helps bring the price down,

00:06:54.758 --> 00:06:58.654
and that's why I said
seven to 10 million there.

00:06:58.678 --> 00:07:02.094
And we're doing it
without a sales-and-marketing team.

00:07:02.118 --> 00:07:04.694
I mean, you're looking
at the sales-and-marketing team.

00:07:04.718 --> 00:07:08.734
We will do it by going
to seven large countries

00:07:08.758 --> 00:07:11.282
and getting them to agree and launch it,

00:07:11.306 --> 00:07:13.614
and then the others can follow.

00:07:13.638 --> 00:07:15.494
We have partners.

00:07:15.518 --> 00:07:17.518
It's not hard to guess
Google would be one.

00:07:17.542 --> 00:07:21.174
The others are all playing to pending.

00:07:21.198 --> 00:07:24.054
And this has been
in the press a great deal.

00:07:24.078 --> 00:07:29.974
It's the so-called Green Machine
that we introduced with Kofi Annan

00:07:29.998 --> 00:07:34.294
in November at the World Summit
that was held in Tunisia.

00:07:34.318 --> 00:07:39.934
Now once people start looking at this,
they say, "Ah, this is a laptop project."

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:43.254
Well, no, it's not a laptop project.
It's an education project.

00:07:43.278 --> 00:07:46.934
And the fun part --
and I'm quite focused on it --

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:51.054
I tell people I used to be a light bulb,
but now I'm a laser --

00:07:51.078 --> 00:07:57.174
I'm just going to get that thing built,
and it turns out it's not so hard.

00:07:57.198 --> 00:08:00.414
Because laptop economics
are the following:

00:08:00.438 --> 00:08:02.934
I say 50 percent here --
it's more like 60,

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.014
60 percent of the cost of your laptop

00:08:05.038 --> 00:08:07.894
is sales, marketing,
distribution and profit.

00:08:07.918 --> 00:08:10.254
Now we have none of those, OK?

00:08:10.278 --> 00:08:13.214
None of those figure into our cost,

00:08:13.238 --> 00:08:17.454
because first of all, we sell it at cost,
and the governments distribute it.

00:08:17.478 --> 00:08:21.734
It gets distributed
to the school system like a textbook.

00:08:21.758 --> 00:08:23.894
So that piece disappears.

00:08:23.918 --> 00:08:26.734
Then you have display and everything else.

00:08:26.758 --> 00:08:29.614
Now the display on your laptop costs,

00:08:29.638 --> 00:08:34.774
in rough numbers,
10 dollars a diagonal inch.

00:08:34.798 --> 00:08:36.934
That can drop to eight;
it can drop to seven

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.934
but it's not going to drop to two,
or to one and a half,

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.718
unless we do some pretty clever things.

00:08:44.038 --> 00:08:48.214
It's the rest -- that little brown box --
that is pretty fascinating,

00:08:48.238 --> 00:08:53.654
because the rest of your laptop
is devoted to itself.

00:08:53.678 --> 00:08:56.294
It's a little bit like an obese person

00:08:56.318 --> 00:08:59.454
having to use most of their energy
to move their obesity.

00:08:59.478 --> 00:09:00.934
(Laughter)

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:06.734
And we have a situation today
which is incredible.

00:09:06.758 --> 00:09:09.734
I've been using laptops
since their inception.

00:09:09.758 --> 00:09:15.094
And my laptop runs slower,
less reliably and less pleasantly

00:09:15.118 --> 00:09:17.654
than it ever has before.

00:09:17.678 --> 00:09:19.174
And this year is worse.

00:09:19.198 --> 00:09:20.574
(Applause)

00:09:20.598 --> 00:09:23.894
People clap, sometimes
you even get standing ovations,

00:09:23.918 --> 00:09:27.614
and I say, "What the hell's wrong
with you? Why are we all sitting there?"

00:09:27.638 --> 00:09:33.974
And somebody -- to remain nameless --
called our laptop a "gadget" recently.

00:09:33.998 --> 00:09:37.614
And I said, "God, our laptop's going to go
like a bat out of hell.

00:09:37.638 --> 00:09:39.834
When you open it up,
it's going to go 'bing.'"

00:09:39.858 --> 00:09:41.134
It'll be on.

00:09:41.158 --> 00:09:44.934
It'll be just like it was in 1985,

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:49.654
when you bought an Apple Macintosh 512.

00:09:49.678 --> 00:09:51.414
It worked really well.

00:09:51.438 --> 00:09:54.534
And we've been going steadily downhill.

00:09:54.558 --> 00:09:58.494
Now, people ask all the time what it is.

00:09:58.518 --> 00:10:00.574
That's what it is.

00:10:00.598 --> 00:10:05.894
The two pieces that are probably notable:
it'll be a mesh network,

00:10:05.918 --> 00:10:09.534
so when the kids open up their laptops,
they all become a network,

00:10:09.558 --> 00:10:12.374
and then just need
one or two points of backhaul.

00:10:12.398 --> 00:10:15.574
You can serve a couple of thousand kids
with two megabits.

00:10:15.598 --> 00:10:18.654
So you really can bring into a village,

00:10:18.678 --> 00:10:20.974
and then the villages
can connect themselves,

00:10:20.998 --> 00:10:24.054
and you really can do it quite well.

00:10:24.078 --> 00:10:26.054
The dual mode display --

00:10:26.078 --> 00:10:30.774
the idea is to have a display
that both works outdoors --

00:10:30.798 --> 00:10:34.214
isn't it fun using your cell phone
outdoors in the sunlight?

00:10:34.238 --> 00:10:35.774
Well, you can't see it.

00:10:35.798 --> 00:10:37.974
And one of the reasons you can't see it

00:10:37.998 --> 00:10:42.054
is because it's backlighting
most of the time, most cell phones.

00:10:42.078 --> 00:10:46.734
Now, what we're doing is, we're doing one
that will be both frontlit and backlit.

00:10:46.758 --> 00:10:50.534
And whether you manually switch it
or you do it in the software

00:10:50.558 --> 00:10:52.054
is to be seen.

00:10:52.078 --> 00:10:53.934
But when it's backlit, it's color.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.014
And when it's frontlit,
it's black and white

00:10:56.038 --> 00:10:58.014
at three times the resolution.

00:10:58.038 --> 00:11:00.494
Is it all worked out? No.

00:11:00.518 --> 00:11:05.774
That's why a lot of our people are
more or less living in Taiwan right now.

00:11:05.798 --> 00:11:10.014
And in about 30 days,
we'll know for sure whether this works.

00:11:10.038 --> 00:11:14.254
Probably the most important piece there

00:11:14.278 --> 00:11:17.414
is that the kids
really can do the maintenance.

00:11:17.438 --> 00:11:20.574
And this is again something
that people don't believe,

00:11:20.598 --> 00:11:22.265
but I really think it's quite true.

00:11:23.838 --> 00:11:28.734
That's the machine we showed in Tunis.

00:11:28.758 --> 00:11:31.534
This is more the direction
that we're going to go.

00:11:31.558 --> 00:11:34.894
And it's something
that we didn't think was possible.

00:11:34.918 --> 00:11:38.254
Now, I'm going to pass this around.

00:11:38.278 --> 00:11:40.454
This isn't a design, OK?

00:11:40.478 --> 00:11:45.174
So this is just a mechanical
engineering sort of embodiment of it

00:11:45.198 --> 00:11:46.734
for you to play with.

00:11:46.758 --> 00:11:48.614
And it's clearly just a model.

00:11:48.638 --> 00:11:51.334
The working one is at MIT.

00:11:51.358 --> 00:11:54.214
I'm going to pass it
to this handsome gentleman.

00:11:54.238 --> 00:11:56.694
At least you can decide
whether it goes left or --

00:11:56.718 --> 00:12:00.018
Chris Anderson: Before you do it,
for the people down in simulcast --

00:12:00.042 --> 00:12:03.104
Nicholas Negroponte: Sorry! I forgot.
CA: Just show it off a bit.

00:12:03.128 --> 00:12:06.134
So wherever the camera is --
OK, good point. Thank you, Chris.

00:12:06.158 --> 00:12:09.734
The idea was that
it would be not only a laptop,

00:12:09.758 --> 00:12:13.334
but that it could transform
into an electronic book.

00:12:13.358 --> 00:12:15.025
So it's sort of an electronic book.

00:12:15.049 --> 00:12:17.811
This is where when you go outside,
it's in black and white.

00:12:17.835 --> 00:12:19.614
The games buttons are missing,

00:12:19.638 --> 00:12:21.933
but it'll also be a games machine,

00:12:21.957 --> 00:12:23.294
book machine.

00:12:23.318 --> 00:12:25.814
Set it up this way,
and it's a television set.

00:12:25.838 --> 00:12:29.958
Etc., etc. -- is that enough
for simulcast? OK, sorry.

00:12:32.118 --> 00:12:34.974
I'll let Jim decide
which way to send it afterwards.

00:12:34.998 --> 00:12:36.694
OK. Seven countries.

00:12:36.718 --> 00:12:38.294
(Laughter)

00:12:38.318 --> 00:12:43.374
I say "maybe" for Massachusetts,
because they actually have to do a bid.

00:12:43.398 --> 00:12:46.054
By law you've got to bid,
and so on and so forth.

00:12:46.078 --> 00:12:47.494
So I can't quite name them.

00:12:47.518 --> 00:12:50.174
In the other cases,
they don't have to do bids.

00:12:50.198 --> 00:12:51.810
They can decide --

00:12:51.834 --> 00:12:53.894
it's the federal government in each case.

00:12:53.918 --> 00:12:55.134
It's kind of agonizing,

00:12:55.158 --> 00:12:58.063
because a lot of people say,
"Let's do it at the state level,"

00:12:58.087 --> 00:13:02.934
because states are more nimble
than the feds, just because of size.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.134
And yet we count.

00:13:04.158 --> 00:13:06.534
We're really dealing
with the federal government.

00:13:06.558 --> 00:13:08.894
We're really dealing
with ministries of education.

00:13:08.918 --> 00:13:11.614
And if you look at governments
around the world,

00:13:11.638 --> 00:13:15.374
ministries of education
tend to be the most conservative,

00:13:15.398 --> 00:13:19.574
and also the ones that have huge payrolls.

00:13:19.598 --> 00:13:21.974
Everybody thinks
they know about education,

00:13:21.998 --> 00:13:24.454
a lot of culture is built into it as well.

00:13:24.478 --> 00:13:28.134
It's really hard.
And so it's certainly the hard road.

00:13:28.158 --> 00:13:32.934
If you look at the countries,
they're pretty geoculturally distributed.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.454
Have they all agreed? No, not completely.

00:13:35.478 --> 00:13:37.854
Probably Thailand, Brazil and Nigeria

00:13:37.878 --> 00:13:40.974
are the three that are
the most active and most agreed.

00:13:40.998 --> 00:13:44.094
We're purposely
not signing anything with anybody

00:13:44.118 --> 00:13:46.414
until we actually have the working ones.

00:13:46.438 --> 00:13:49.094
And since I visit
each one of those countries

00:13:49.118 --> 00:13:51.134
within at least every three months,

00:13:51.158 --> 00:13:54.294
I'm just going around the world
every three weeks.

00:13:54.318 --> 00:13:55.854
Here's sort of the schedule

00:13:55.878 --> 00:14:02.078
and I put at the bottom we might give some
away free in two years at this meeting.

00:14:02.380 --> 00:14:05.493
Everybody says it's a $100 laptop --

00:14:05.517 --> 00:14:06.668
you can't do it.

00:14:06.692 --> 00:14:08.094
Well, guess what, we're not.

00:14:08.118 --> 00:14:13.174
We're coming in probably at 135,
to start, then drift down.

00:14:13.198 --> 00:14:14.654
And that's very important,

00:14:14.678 --> 00:14:19.974
because so many things hit the market
at a price and then drift up.

00:14:19.998 --> 00:14:21.494
It's kind of the loss leader,

00:14:21.518 --> 00:14:24.374
and then as soon as it looks interesting,

00:14:24.398 --> 00:14:27.054
it can't be afforded,
or it can't be scaled out.

00:14:27.078 --> 00:14:30.494
So we're targeting 50 dollars in 2010.

00:14:30.518 --> 00:14:32.294
The gray market's a big issue.

00:14:32.318 --> 00:14:34.694
And one of the ways -- just one --

00:14:34.718 --> 00:14:38.774
but one of the ways to help
in the case of the gray market

00:14:38.798 --> 00:14:41.334
is to make something
that is so utterly unique --

00:14:41.358 --> 00:14:44.974
It's a little bit like the fact
that automobiles --

00:14:44.998 --> 00:14:48.654
thousands of automobiles
are stolen every day in the United States.

00:14:48.678 --> 00:14:51.614
Not one single
post-office truck is stolen.

00:14:51.638 --> 00:14:52.854
(Laughter)

00:14:52.878 --> 00:14:54.054
And why?

00:14:54.078 --> 00:14:56.414
Because there's no market
for post-office trucks.

00:14:56.438 --> 00:14:58.174
It looks like a post-office truck.

00:14:58.198 --> 00:15:00.675
You can spray paint it.
You can do anything you want.

00:15:00.699 --> 00:15:04.894
I just learned recently: in South Africa,
no white Volvos are stolen.

00:15:04.918 --> 00:15:06.494
Period. None. Zero.

00:15:06.518 --> 00:15:10.533
So we want to make it
very much like a white Volvo.

00:15:11.318 --> 00:15:13.534
Each government has a task force.

00:15:13.558 --> 00:15:15.174
This perhaps is less interesting,

00:15:15.198 --> 00:15:18.103
but we're trying to get the governments
to all work together

00:15:18.127 --> 00:15:20.562
and it's not easy.

00:15:21.838 --> 00:15:26.885
The economics of this
is to start with the federal governments

00:15:26.909 --> 00:15:33.891
and then later,
to subsequently go to other --

00:15:33.915 --> 00:15:35.811
whether it's child-to-child funding,

00:15:35.835 --> 00:15:40.294
so a child in this country buys one
for a child in the developing world,

00:15:40.318 --> 00:15:43.414
maybe of the same gender,
maybe of the same age.

00:15:43.438 --> 00:15:47.134
An uncle gives a niece or a nephew that
as a birthday present.

00:15:47.158 --> 00:15:49.854
I mean, there are all sorts of things
that will happen,

00:15:49.878 --> 00:15:51.774
and they'll be very, very exciting.

00:15:51.798 --> 00:15:56.793
And everybody says -- I say --
it's an education project.

00:15:56.817 --> 00:15:58.814
Are we providing the software?

00:15:58.838 --> 00:16:00.323
The answer is:

00:16:00.347 --> 00:16:01.974
The system certainly has software,

00:16:01.998 --> 00:16:05.134
but no, we're not providing
the education content.

00:16:05.158 --> 00:16:09.254
That is really done in the countries.

00:16:09.278 --> 00:16:11.354
But we are certainly constructionists.

00:16:11.378 --> 00:16:13.534
And we certainly believe
in learning by doing

00:16:13.558 --> 00:16:17.694
and everything from Logo,
which was started in 1968,

00:16:17.718 --> 00:16:22.694
to more modern things, like Scratch,
if you've ever even heard of it,

00:16:22.718 --> 00:16:24.774
are very, very much part of it.

00:16:24.798 --> 00:16:26.641
And that's the rollout.

00:16:27.838 --> 00:16:30.077
Are we dreaming? Is this real?

00:16:30.101 --> 00:16:31.766
It actually is real.

00:16:32.718 --> 00:16:37.454
The only criticism, and people
really don't want to criticize this,

00:16:37.478 --> 00:16:41.334
because it is a humanitarian effort,
a nonprofit effort

00:16:41.358 --> 00:16:45.174
and to criticize it
is a little bit stupid, actually.

00:16:45.198 --> 00:16:46.414
(Laughter)

00:16:46.438 --> 00:16:52.574
But the one thing
that people could criticize was,

00:16:52.598 --> 00:16:56.162
"Great idea, but these guys can't do it."

00:16:56.758 --> 00:17:00.934
And that could either mean these guys,
professors and so on couldn't do it,

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:02.934
or that it's not possible.

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:08.654
Well, on December 12, a company
called Quanta agreed to build it,

00:17:08.678 --> 00:17:13.614
and since they make about one-third
of all the laptops on the planet today,

00:17:13.638 --> 00:17:15.214
that question disappeared.

00:17:15.238 --> 00:17:18.454
So it's not a matter
of whether it's going to happen.

00:17:18.478 --> 00:17:19.694
It is going to happen.

00:17:19.718 --> 00:17:24.138
And if it comes out
at 138 dollars, so what?

00:17:24.162 --> 00:17:27.188
If it comes out six months late, so what?

00:17:27.188 --> 00:17:28.888
That's a pretty soft landing.

00:17:28.888 --> 00:17:30.448
Thank you.

00:17:30.448 --> 00:17:32.037
(Applause)

title: An 11-year-old's magical violin
transcript: (Music)(Music ends)(Applause)(Applause ends)Hi, everyone. I'm Sirena. I'm 11 years old and from Connecticut. (Audience cheers)(Applause)Well, I'm not really sure why I'm here.(Laughter)I mean, what does this have to do with technology, entertainment and design? Well, I count my iPod, cellphone and computer as technology, but this has nothing to do with that.So I did a little research on it. Well, this is what I found. Of course, I hope I can memorize it.(Clears throat)The violin is made of a wood box and four metal strings. By pulling a string, it vibrates and produces a sound wave, which passes through a piece of wood called a bridge, and goes down to the wood box and gets amplified, but ... let me think.(Laughter)Placing your finger at different places on the fingerboard changes the string length, and that changes the frequency of the sound wave. (Sighs) Oh, my gosh!(Laughter)OK, this is sort of technology, but I can call it a 16th-century technology. But actually, the most fascinating thing that I found was that even the audio system or wave transmission nowadays are still based on the same principle of producing and projecting sound. Isn't that cool?(Laughter)(Applause)Design — I love its design. I remember when I was little, my mom asked me, "Would you like to play the violin or the piano?" I looked at that giant monster and said to myself — "I am not going to lock myself on that bench the whole day!"(Laughter)This is small and lightweight. I can play from standing, sitting or walking. And, you know what? The best of all is that if I don't want to practice, (Whispering) I can hide it.(Laughter)The violin is very beautiful. Some people relate it as the shape of a lady. But whether you like it or not, it's been so for more than 400 years, unlike modern stuff [that] easily looks dated. But I think it's very personal and unique that, although each violin looks pretty similar, no two violins sound the same — even from the same maker or based on the same model.Entertainment — I love the entertainment. But actually, the instrument itself isn't very entertaining. I mean, when I first got my violin and tried to play around on it, it was actually really bad, because it didn't sound the way I'd heard from other kids — it was so horrible and so scratchy. So, it wasn't entertaining at all. But besides, my brother found this very funny: Yuk! Yuk! Yuk!(Laughter)A few years later, I heard a joke about the greatest violinist, Jascha Heifetz. After Mr. Heifetz's concert, a lady came over and complimented him: "Oh, Mr. Heifetz, your violin sounded so great tonight!" And Mr. Heifetz was a very cool person, so he picked up his violin and said, "Funny — I don't hear anything."(Laughter)Now I realize that as the musician, we human beings, with our great mind, artistic heart and skill, can change this 16th-century technology and a legendary design to a wonderful entertainment. Now I know why I'm here.(Music)(Music ends)(Applause)At first, I thought I was just going to be here to perform, but unexpectedly, I learned and enjoyed much more. But ... although some of the talks were quite up there for me.(Laughter)Like the multi-dimension stuff. I mean, honestly, I'd be happy enough if I could actually get my two dimensions correct in school.(Laughter)But actually, the most impressive thing to me is that — well, actually, I would also like to say this for all children is to say thank you to all adults, for actually caring for us a lot, and to make our future world much better. Thank you.(Applause)(Music)(Music ends)(Applause)(Applause ends)(Music)(Music ends)(Applause)

title: Improvising on piano, aged 14
transcript: (Music)(Music ends)(Applause)Thank you!(Applause continues)Thank you very much. Like the speaker before me — I am a TED virgin, I guess. I'm also the first time here, and ...(Laughter)I don't know what to say!(Applause)I'm really happy that Mr. Anderson invited me. I'm really grateful that I get a chance to play for everyone. And the song that I just played was by Josef Hofmann. It's called "Kaleidoscope." And Hofmann is a Polish pianist and composer of the late 19th century, and he's widely considered one of the greatest pianists of all time.I have another piece that I'd like to play for you. It's called "Abegg Variations," by Robert Schumann, a German 19th-century composer. The name "Abegg" is actually A-B-E-G-G, and that's the main theme in the melody. (Plays the notes A, B, E, G and G) That comes from the last name of one of Schumann's female friends.(Laughter)But he wrote that for his wife.(Laughter)So actually, if you listen carefully, there are supposed to be five variations on this Abegg theme. It's written around 1834, so even though it's old, I hope you'll like it.(Music)(Music ends)(Applause)Now comes the part that I hate. Well, because Mr. Anderson told me that this session is called "Sync and Flow," I was wondering, "What do I know that these geniuses don't?"(Laughter)So, I'll talk about musical composition, even though I don't know where to start.How do I compose? I think Yamaha does a really good job of teaching us how to compose. What I do first is, I make a lot of little musical ideas you can just improvise here at the piano — and I choose one of those to become my main theme, my main melody, like the Abegg that you just heard. And once I choose my main theme, I have to decide: Out of all the styles in music, what kind of style do I want? And this year, I composed a Romantic style. So for inspiration, I listened to Liszt and Tchaikovsky and all the great Romantic composers.Next, I make the structure of the entire piece with my teachers. They help me plan out the whole piece. And then the hard part is filling it in with musical ideas, because then you have to think.(Laughter)And then, when the piece takes somewhat of a solified form — solidified, excuse me — solidified form, you're supposed to actually polish the piece, polish the details, and then polish the overall performance of the composition.And another thing that I enjoy doing is drawing. Drawing, because I like to draw, you know, Japanese anime art. I think that's a craze among teens right now. And once I realized it, there's a parallel between creating music and creating art, because for your motive, or your little initial idea for your drawing, it's your character — you want to decide who you want to draw, or if you want to draw an original character. And then you want to decide: How are you going to draw the character? Like, am I going to use one page? Am I going to draw it on the computer? Am I going to use a two-page spread like a comic book? For a more grandiose effect, I guess. And then you have to do the initial sketch of the character, which is like your structure of a piece, and then you add pen and pencil, and whatever details that you need — that's polishing the drawing.And another thing that both of these have in common is your state of mind, because I know I'm one of those teenagers that are really easily distracted. So if I'm trying to do homework and I don't feel like it, I'll try to draw or, you know, waste my time. And then what happens is, sometimes I absolutely can't draw or I can't compose at all, and then it's like there's too much on your mind. You can't focus on what you're supposed to do. And sometimes, if you manage to use your time wisely and work on it, you'll get something out of it, but it doesn't come naturally.What happens is, if something magical happens, if something natural happens to you, you're able to produce all this beautiful stuff instantly, and then that's what I consider "flow," because that's when everything clicks and you're able to do anything. You feel like you're on top of your game and you can do anything you want.I'm not going to play my own composition today because, although I did finish it, it's way too long. Instead, I'd like to try something called "improvisation." I have here seven note cards, one with each note of the musical alphabet. And I'd like someone to come up here and choose five — anyone to come up here and choose five — and then I can make it into some sort of melody, and I'll improvise it. Wow. A volunteer, yay!(Laughter)(Applause)Jennifer Lin: Nice to meet you.Goldie Hawn: Thank you. Choose five?JL: Yes, five cards. Any five cards.GH: OK, one. JL: OK.GH: Two. JL: Yes.GH: Three.GH: Oh, D and F — too familiar.(Laughter)JL: One more. GH: OK. "E" for "effort."JL: Would you mind reading them out in the order that you chose them?GH: OK — C, G, B, A and E.JL: Thank you very much!GH: You're welcome. And what about these?JL: I won't use them. Thank you!(Applause)Now, she chose C, G, B, A, E. I'm going to try to put that in some sort of order.(Plays notes)OK, that's nice. So, I'm going to have a moment to think, and I'll try to make something out of it.(Plays the five notes)(Music)(Music ends)(Applause)The next song, or the encore that I'm going to play is called "Bumble Boogie," by Jack Fina.(Applause)(Music)(Music ends)(Applause)

by Robert Schumann,

00:05:36.754 --> 00:05:39.595
a German 19th-century composer.

00:05:40.952 --> 00:05:45.103
The name "Abegg" is actually A-B-E-G-G,

00:05:45.127 --> 00:05:47.070
and that's the main theme in the melody.

00:05:47.094 --> 00:05:49.593
(Plays the notes A, B, E, G and G)

00:05:50.965 --> 00:05:54.730
That comes from the last name
of one of Schumann's female friends.

00:05:55.631 --> 00:05:57.404
(Laughter)

00:05:57.428 --> 00:05:59.531
But he wrote that for his wife.

00:05:59.555 --> 00:06:02.933
(Laughter)

00:06:03.673 --> 00:06:05.499
So actually, if you listen carefully,

00:06:05.523 --> 00:06:08.511
there are supposed to be
five variations on this Abegg theme.

00:06:08.944 --> 00:06:11.548
It's written around 1834,

00:06:11.572 --> 00:06:13.849
so even though it's old,
I hope you'll like it.

00:06:17.541 --> 00:06:22.934
(Music)

00:13:06.945 --> 00:13:08.945
(Music ends)

00:13:10.270 --> 00:13:17.129
(Applause)

00:13:17.706 --> 00:13:19.310
Now comes the part that I hate.

00:13:22.549 --> 00:13:25.005
Well, because Mr. Anderson told me

00:13:25.029 --> 00:13:27.906
that this session is called
"Sync and Flow,"

00:13:27.930 --> 00:13:30.927
I was wondering, "What do I know
that these geniuses don't?"

00:13:30.951 --> 00:13:32.118
(Laughter)

00:13:32.142 --> 00:13:34.267
So, I'll talk about musical composition,

00:13:34.291 --> 00:13:36.272
even though I don't know where to start.

00:13:37.637 --> 00:13:38.958
How do I compose?

00:13:39.502 --> 00:13:43.013
I think Yamaha does a really good job
of teaching us how to compose.

00:13:43.410 --> 00:13:47.097
What I do first is, I make a lot
of little musical ideas

00:13:47.121 --> 00:13:49.312
you can just improvise
here at the piano --

00:13:49.336 --> 00:13:53.053
and I choose one of those
to become my main theme, my main melody,

00:13:53.077 --> 00:13:54.958
like the Abegg that you just heard.

00:13:55.258 --> 00:13:58.760
And once I choose my main theme,
I have to decide:

00:13:58.784 --> 00:14:02.126
Out of all the styles in music,
what kind of style do I want?

00:14:02.586 --> 00:14:05.177
And this year,
I composed a Romantic style.

00:14:05.526 --> 00:14:09.403
So for inspiration,
I listened to Liszt and Tchaikovsky

00:14:09.427 --> 00:14:11.402
and all the great Romantic composers.

00:14:11.918 --> 00:14:16.958
Next, I make the structure
of the entire piece with my teachers.

00:14:17.401 --> 00:14:19.346
They help me plan out the whole piece.

00:14:19.370 --> 00:14:23.072
And then the hard part
is filling it in with musical ideas,

00:14:23.096 --> 00:14:25.070
because then you have to think.

00:14:25.094 --> 00:14:26.867
(Laughter)

00:14:26.891 --> 00:14:30.370
And then, when the piece
takes somewhat of a solified form --

00:14:30.394 --> 00:14:32.616
solidified, excuse me -- solidified form,

00:14:32.640 --> 00:14:37.666
you're supposed to actually
polish the piece, polish the details,

00:14:37.690 --> 00:14:40.958
and then polish the overall
performance of the composition.

00:14:41.801 --> 00:14:44.846
And another thing
that I enjoy doing is drawing.

00:14:44.870 --> 00:14:48.354
Drawing, because I like to draw,
you know, Japanese anime art.

00:14:48.378 --> 00:14:50.661
I think that's a craze
among teens right now.

00:14:51.343 --> 00:14:52.995
And once I realized it,

00:14:53.019 --> 00:14:57.015
there's a parallel between creating
music and creating art,

00:14:57.039 --> 00:15:02.149
because for your motive, or your
little initial idea for your drawing,

00:15:02.173 --> 00:15:05.141
it's your character -- you want
to decide who you want to draw,

00:15:05.165 --> 00:15:07.321
or if you want to draw
an original character.

00:15:07.345 --> 00:15:10.842
And then you want to decide:
How are you going to draw the character?

00:15:10.866 --> 00:15:14.278
Like, am I going to use one page?
Am I going to draw it on the computer?

00:15:14.302 --> 00:15:17.478
Am I going to use a two-page spread
like a comic book?

00:15:17.502 --> 00:15:19.705
For a more grandiose effect, I guess.

00:15:20.089 --> 00:15:23.236
And then you have to do
the initial sketch of the character,

00:15:23.260 --> 00:15:25.298
which is like your structure of a piece,

00:15:25.322 --> 00:15:29.082
and then you add pen and pencil,
and whatever details that you need --

00:15:29.106 --> 00:15:30.602
that's polishing the drawing.

00:15:30.983 --> 00:15:34.705
And another thing that both of these
have in common is your state of mind,

00:15:34.729 --> 00:15:39.715
because I know I'm one of those teenagers
that are really easily distracted.

00:15:39.739 --> 00:15:44.754
So if I'm trying to do homework
and I don't feel like it,

00:15:44.778 --> 00:15:47.531
I'll try to draw or,
you know, waste my time.

00:15:47.957 --> 00:15:50.735
And then what happens is,
sometimes I absolutely can't draw

00:15:50.759 --> 00:15:52.720
or I can't compose at all,

00:15:52.744 --> 00:15:55.050
and then it's like
there's too much on your mind.

00:15:55.074 --> 00:15:57.451
You can't focus
on what you're supposed to do.

00:15:57.475 --> 00:16:02.776
And sometimes, if you manage to use
your time wisely and work on it,

00:16:02.800 --> 00:16:05.889
you'll get something out of it,
but it doesn't come naturally.

00:16:06.444 --> 00:16:08.928
What happens is,
if something magical happens,

00:16:08.952 --> 00:16:11.556
if something natural happens to you,

00:16:11.580 --> 00:16:15.199
you're able to produce
all this beautiful stuff instantly,

00:16:15.223 --> 00:16:17.351
and then that's what I consider "flow,"

00:16:17.375 --> 00:16:21.343
because that's when everything clicks
and you're able to do anything.

00:16:21.367 --> 00:16:25.128
You feel like you're on top of your game
and you can do anything you want.

00:16:25.152 --> 00:16:28.373
I'm not going to play
my own composition today because,

00:16:28.397 --> 00:16:30.958
although I did finish it,
it's way too long.

00:16:32.008 --> 00:16:35.196
Instead, I'd like to try something
called "improvisation."

00:16:35.220 --> 00:16:37.441
I have here seven note cards,

00:16:37.465 --> 00:16:40.648
one with each note
of the musical alphabet.

00:16:40.672 --> 00:16:44.555
And I'd like someone to come up here
and choose five --

00:16:44.579 --> 00:16:46.567
anyone to come up here and choose five --

00:16:46.591 --> 00:16:49.303
and then I can make it
into some sort of melody,

00:16:49.327 --> 00:16:50.707
and I'll improvise it.

00:16:51.669 --> 00:16:54.800
Wow. A volunteer, yay!

00:16:54.824 --> 00:16:56.298
(Laughter)

00:16:56.322 --> 00:16:59.448
(Applause)

00:16:59.472 --> 00:17:01.083
Jennifer Lin: Nice to meet you.

00:17:01.591 --> 00:17:04.578
Goldie Hawn: Thank you. Choose five?

00:17:04.602 --> 00:17:06.664
JL: Yes, five cards. Any five cards.

00:17:06.688 --> 00:17:08.254
GH: OK, one.
JL: OK.

00:17:09.143 --> 00:17:10.714
GH: Two.
JL: Yes.

00:17:11.983 --> 00:17:13.134
GH: Three.

00:17:14.967 --> 00:17:17.466
GH: Oh, D and F -- too familiar.

00:17:17.490 --> 00:17:22.099
(Laughter)

00:17:22.123 --> 00:17:25.459
JL: One more.
GH: OK. "E" for "effort."

00:17:25.483 --> 00:17:28.754
JL: Would you mind reading them out
in the order that you chose them?

00:17:28.778 --> 00:17:35.069
GH: OK -- C, G, B, A and E.

00:17:35.093 --> 00:17:36.247
JL: Thank you very much!

00:17:36.271 --> 00:17:38.247
GH: You're welcome. And what about these?

00:17:38.271 --> 00:17:40.797
JL: I won't use them. Thank you!

00:17:42.162 --> 00:17:48.419
(Applause)

00:17:49.110 --> 00:17:52.488
Now, she chose C, G, B, A, E.

00:17:52.512 --> 00:17:54.932
I'm going to try to put that
in some sort of order.

00:17:54.956 --> 00:17:58.468
(Plays notes)

00:18:00.564 --> 00:18:02.302
OK, that's nice.

00:18:02.994 --> 00:18:04.931
So, I'm going to have a moment to think,

00:18:04.955 --> 00:18:07.197
and I'll try to make something out of it.

00:18:12.092 --> 00:18:15.340
(Plays the five notes)

00:18:23.002 --> 00:18:29.855
(Music)

00:21:39.159 --> 00:21:41.160
(Music ends)

00:21:41.184 --> 00:21:47.962
(Applause)

00:21:47.986 --> 00:21:50.550
The next song, or the encore
that I'm going to play

00:21:50.574 --> 00:21:53.958
is called "Bumble Boogie," by Jack Fina.

00:21:54.937 --> 00:21:56.246
(Applause)

00:21:59.647 --> 00:22:05.372
(Music)

00:23:51.479 --> 00:23:53.480
(Music ends)

00:23:53.504 --> 00:23:59.958
(Applause)

title: Simple designs to save a life
transcript: In terms of invention, I'd like to tell you the tale of one of my favorite projects. I think it's one of the most exciting that I'm working on, but I think it's also the simplest.It's a project that has the potential to make a huge impact around the world. It addresses one of the biggest health issues on the planet, the number one cause of death in children under five. Which is ...? Water-borne diseases? Diarrhea? Malnutrition? No. It's breathing the smoke from indoor cooking fires — acute respiratory infections caused by this. Can you believe that?I find this shocking and somewhat appalling. Can't we make cleaner burning cooking fuels? Can't we make better stoves? How is it that this can lead to over two million deaths every year? I know Bill Joy was talking to you about the wonders of carbon nanotubes, so I'm going to talk to you about the wonders of carbon macro-tubes, which is charcoal.(Laughter)So this is a picture of rural Haiti. Haiti is now 98 percent deforested. You'll see scenes like this all over the island. It leads to all sorts of environmental problems and problems that affect people throughout the nation. A couple years ago there was severe flooding that led to thousands of deaths — that's directly attributable to the fact that there are no trees on the hills to stabilize the soil. So the rains come — they go down the rivers and the flooding happens.Now one of the reasons why there are so few trees is this: people need to cook, and they harvest wood and they make charcoal in order to do it. It's not that people are ignorant to the environmental damage. They know perfectly well, but they have no other choice. Fossil fuels are not available, and solar energy doesn't cook the way that they like their food prepared. And so this is what they do. You'll find families like this who go out into the forest to find a tree, cut it down and make charcoal out of it. So not surprisingly, there's a lot of effort that's been done to look at alternative cooking fuels.About four years ago, I took a team of students down to Haiti and we worked with Peace Corps volunteers there. This is one such volunteer and this is a device that he had built in the village where he worked. And the idea was that you could take waste paper; you could compress it and make briquettes that could be used for fuel. But this device was very slow. So our engineering students went to work on it and with some very simple changes, they were able to triple the throughput of this device. So you could imagine they were very excited about it. And they took the briquettes back to MIT so that they could test them. And one of the things that they found was they didn't burn. So it was a little discouraging to the students.(Laughter)And in fact, if you look closely, right here you can see it says, "US Peace Corps." As it turns out, there actually wasn't any waste paper in this village. And while it was a good use of government paperwork for this volunteer to bring it back with him to his village, it was 800 kilometers away. And so we thought perhaps there might be a better way to come up with an alternative cooking fuel.What we wanted to do is we wanted to make a fuel that used something that was readily available on the local level. You see these all over Haiti as well. They're small-scale sugar mills. And the waste product from them after you extract the juice from the sugarcane is called "bagasse." It has no other use. It has no nutritional value, so they don't feed it to the animals. It just sits in a pile near the sugar mill until eventually they burn it. What we wanted to do was we wanted to find a way to harness this waste resource and turn it into a fuel that would be something that people could easily cook with, something like charcoal. So over the next couple of years, students and I worked to develop a process.So you start with the bagasse, and then you take a very simple kiln that you can make out of a waste fifty five-gallon oil drum. After some time, after setting it on fire, you seal it to restrict the oxygen that goes into the kiln, and then you end up with this carbonized material here. However, you can't burn this. It's too fine and it burns too quickly to be useful for cooking. So we had to try to find a way to form it into useful briquettes. And conveniently, one of my students was from Ghana, and he remembered a dish his mom used to make for him called "kokonte," which is a very sticky porridge made out of the cassava root. And so what we did was we looked, and we found that cassava is indeed grown in Haiti, under the name of "manioc." In fact, it's grown all over the world — yucca, tapioca, manioc, cassava, it's all the same thing — a very starchy root vegetable. And you can make a very thick, sticky porridge out of it, which you can use to bind together the charcoal briquettes. So we did this. We went down to Haiti. These are the graduates of the first Ecole de Charbon, or Charcoal Institute. And these —(Laughter)That's right. So I'm actually an instructor at MIT as well as CIT. And these are the briquettes that we made.Now I'm going to take you to a different continent. This is India and this is the most commonly used cooking fuel in India. It's cow dung. And more than in Haiti, this produces really smoky fires, and this is where you see the health impacts of cooking with cow dung and biomass as a fuel. Kids and women are especially affected by it, because they're the ones who are around the cooking fires.So we wanted to see if we could introduce this charcoal-making technology there. Well, unfortunately, they didn't have sugarcane and they didn't have cassava, but that didn't stop us. What we did was we found what were the locally available sources of biomass. And there was wheat straw and there was rice straw in this area. And what we could use as a binder was actually small amounts of cow manure, which they used ordinarily for their fuel. And we did side-by-side tests, and here you can see the charcoal briquettes and here the cow dung. And you can see that it's a lot cleaner burning of a cooking fuel. And in fact, it heats the water a lot more quickly. And so we were very happy, thus far. But one of the things that we found was when we did side-by-side comparisons with wood charcoal, it didn't burn as long. And the briquettes crumbled a little bit and we lost energy as they fell apart as they were cooking. So we wanted to try to find a way to make a stronger briquette so that we could compete with wood charcoal in the markets in Haiti.So we went back to MIT, we took out the Instron machine and we figured out what sort of forces you needed in order to compress a briquette to the level that you actually are getting improved performance out of it? And at the same time that we had students in the lab looking at this, we also had community partners in Haiti working to develop the process, to improve it and make it more accessible to people in the villages there. And after some time, we developed a low-cost press that allows you to produce charcoal, which actually now burns not only — actually, it burns longer, cleaner than wood charcoal.So now we're in a situation where we have a product, which is actually better than what you can buy in Haiti in the marketplace, which is a very wonderful place to be. In Haiti alone, about 30 million trees are cut down every year. There's a possibility of this being implemented and saving a good portion of those. In addition, the revenue generated from that charcoal is 260 million dollars. That's an awful lot for a country like Haiti — with a population of eight million and an average income of less than 400 dollars. So this is where we're also moving ahead with our charcoal project.And one of the things that I think is also interesting, is I have a friend up at UC Berkeley who's been doing risk analysis. And he's looked at the problem of the health impacts of burning wood versus charcoal. And he's found that worldwide, you could prevent a million deaths switching from wood to charcoal as a cooking fuel. That's remarkable, but up until now, there weren't ways to do it without cutting down trees. But now we have a way that's using an agricultural waste material to create a cooking fuel.One of the really exciting things, though, is something that came out of the trip that I took to Ghana just last month. And I think it's the coolest thing, and it's even lower tech than what you just saw, if you can imagine such a thing. Here it is. So what is this? This is corncobs turned into charcoal. And the beauty of this is that you don't need to form briquettes — it comes ready made. This is my $100 laptop, right here. And actually, like Nick, I brought samples.(Laughter)So we can pass these around. They're fully functional, field-tested, ready to roll out.(Laughter)And I think one of the things which is also remarkable about this technology, is that the technology transfer is so easy. Compared to the sugarcane charcoal, where we have to teach people how to form it into briquettes and you have the extra step of cooking the binder, this comes pre-briquetted. And this is about the most exciting thing in my life right now, which is perhaps a sad commentary on my life.(Laughter)But once you see it, like you guys in the front row — All right, yeah, OK. So anyway —(Laughter)Here it is. And this is, I think, a perfect example of what Robert Wright was talking about in those non-zero-sum things. So not only do you have health benefits, you have environmental benefits. But this is one of the incredibly rare situations where you also have economic benefits. People can make their own cooking fuel from waste products. They can generate income from this. They can save the money that they were going to spend on charcoal and they can produce excess and sell it in the market to people who aren't making their own. It's really rare that you don't have trade-offs between health and economics, or environment and economics. So this is a project that I just find extremely exciting and I'm really looking forward to see where it takes us.So when we talk about, now, the future we will create, one of the things that I think is necessary is to have a very clear vision of the world that we live in. And now, I don't actually mean the world that we live in. I mean the world where women spend two to three hours everyday grinding grain for their families to eat. I mean the world where advanced building materials means cement roofing tiles that are made by hand, and where, when you work 10 hours a day, you're still only earning 60 dollars in a month. I mean the world where women and children spend 40 billion hours a year fetching water. That's as if the entire workforce of the state of California worked full time for a year doing nothing but fetching water.It's a place where, for example, if this were India, in this room, only three of us would have a car. If this were Afghanistan, only one person in this room would know how the use the Internet. If this were Zambia — 300 of you would be farmers, 100 of you would have AIDS or HIV. And more than half of you would be living on less than a dollar a day. These are the issues that we need to come up with solutions for. These are the issues that we need to be training our engineers, our designers, our business people, our entrepreneurs to be facing. These are the solutions that we need to find.I have a few areas that I believe are especially important that we address. One of them is creating technologies to promote micro-finance and micro-enterprise, so that people who are living below the poverty line can find a way to move out — and that they're not doing it using the same traditional basket making, poultry rearing, etc. But there are new technologies and new products that they can make on a small scale.The next thing I believe is that we need to create technologies for poor farmers to add value to their own crops. And we need to rethink our development strategies, so that we're not promoting educational campaigns to get them to stop being farmers, but rather to stop being poor farmers. And we need to think about how we can do that effectively. We need to work with the people in these communities and give them the resources and the tools that they need to solve their own problems. That's the best way to do it. We shouldn't be doing it from outside. So we need to create this future, and we need to start doing it now.Thank you.(Applause)Chris Anderson: Thank you, incredible. Stay here. Tell us — just while we see if someone has a question — just tell us about one of the other things that you've worked on.Amy Smith: Some of the other things we're working on are ways to do low-cost water quality testing, so that communities can maintain their own water systems, know when they're working, know when they treat them, etc. We're also looking at low-cost water-treatment systems. One of the really exciting things is looking at solar water disinfection and improving the ability to be able to do that.CA: What's the bottleneck preventing this stuff getting from scale? Do you need to find entrepreneurs, or venture capitalists, or what do you need to take what you've got and get it to scale?AS: I think it's large numbers of people moving it forward. It's a difficult thing — it's a marketplace which is very fragmented and a consumer population with no income. So you can't use the same models that you use in the United States for making things move forward. And we're a pretty small staff, which is me.(Laughter)So, you know, I do what I can with the students. We have 30 students a year go out into the field and try to implement this and move it forward. The other thing is you have to do things with a long time frame, as, you know, you can't expect to get something done in a year or two years; you have to be looking five or 10 years ahead. But I think with the vision to do that, we can move forward.
