00:05:51.518 --> 00:05:53.134
is what I'm trying to understand.

00:05:53.158 --> 00:05:56.054
This is a scan through the human forearm.

00:05:56.078 --> 00:05:59.094
It's then blown up
through rapid prototyping

00:05:59.118 --> 00:06:00.694
to reveal its cellular structure.

00:06:00.718 --> 00:06:02.214
I have these in my office.

00:06:02.238 --> 00:06:05.254
My office is a mixture
of the Natural History Museum

00:06:05.278 --> 00:06:06.934
and a NASA space lab.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.774
It's a weird, kind of freaky place.

00:06:09.798 --> 00:06:11.894
This is one of my specimens.

00:06:11.918 --> 00:06:13.134
This is made --

00:06:13.158 --> 00:06:19.934
bone is made from a mixture
of inorganic minerals and polymers.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:24.694
I studied cooking in school
for four years, and in that experience,

00:06:24.718 --> 00:06:26.433
which was called "domestic science,"

00:06:26.457 --> 00:06:30.029
it was a bit of a cheap trick for me
to try and get a science qualification.

00:06:30.053 --> 00:06:31.614
(Laughter)

00:06:31.638 --> 00:06:34.334
Actually, I put marijuana
in everything I cooked --

00:06:34.358 --> 00:06:35.574
(Laughter)

00:06:35.598 --> 00:06:38.218
And I had access to all
the best girls. It was fabulous.

00:06:38.242 --> 00:06:40.623
All the guys in the rugby team
couldn't understand.

00:06:40.647 --> 00:06:42.214
Anyway -- this is a meringue.

00:06:42.238 --> 00:06:43.694
This is another sample I have.

00:06:43.718 --> 00:06:47.094
A meringue is made exactly the same way,
in my estimation, as a bone.

00:06:47.118 --> 00:06:50.774
It's made from
polysaccharides and proteins.

00:06:50.798 --> 00:06:52.974
If you pour water on that, it dissolves.

00:06:52.998 --> 00:06:56.654
Could we be manufacturing
from foodstuffs in the future?

00:06:56.678 --> 00:06:58.454
Not a bad idea. I don't know.

00:06:58.478 --> 00:07:01.240
I need to talk to Janine
and a few other people about that,

00:07:01.264 --> 00:07:05.054
but I believe instinctively that
that meringue can become something,

00:07:05.078 --> 00:07:06.278
a car -- I don't know.

00:07:07.276 --> 00:07:09.134
I'm also interested in growth patterns:

00:07:09.158 --> 00:07:13.654
the unbridled way that nature grows things

00:07:13.678 --> 00:07:16.254
so you're not restricted by form at all.

00:07:16.278 --> 00:07:19.934
These interrelated forms,
they do inspire everything I do,

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:23.414
although I might end up
making something incredibly simple.

00:07:23.438 --> 00:07:26.654
This is a detail of a chair
that I've designed in magnesium.

00:07:26.678 --> 00:07:31.734
It shows this interlocution of elements
and the beauty of, kind of, engineering

00:07:31.758 --> 00:07:33.743
and biological thinking,

00:07:33.767 --> 00:07:35.854
shown pretty much as a bone structure.

00:07:35.878 --> 00:07:38.694
Any one of those elements
you could sort of hang on the wall

00:07:38.718 --> 00:07:40.374
as some kind of art object.

00:07:40.398 --> 00:07:43.174
It's the world's first chair
made in magnesium.

00:07:43.198 --> 00:07:45.254
It cost 1.7 million dollars to develop.

00:07:45.278 --> 00:07:48.254
It's called "Go," by Bernhardt, USA.

00:07:48.278 --> 00:07:54.014
It went into Time magazine in 2001
as the new language of the 21st century.

00:07:54.038 --> 00:07:57.838
Boy. For somebody growing up in Wales
in a little village, that's enough.

00:07:59.158 --> 00:08:02.134
It shows how you make one holistic form,
like the car industry,

00:08:02.158 --> 00:08:03.873
and then you break up what you need.

00:08:03.897 --> 00:08:06.094
This is an absolutely
beautiful way of working.

00:08:06.118 --> 00:08:08.374
It's a godly way of working.

00:08:08.398 --> 00:08:10.654
It's organic and it's essential.

00:08:10.678 --> 00:08:12.345
It's an absolutely fat-free design,

00:08:12.369 --> 00:08:16.254
and when you look at it,
you see human beings.

00:08:16.278 --> 00:08:17.707
When that moves into polymers,

00:08:17.731 --> 00:08:22.094
you can change the elasticity,
the fluidity of the form.

00:08:22.118 --> 00:08:25.734
This is an idea for a gas-injected,
one-piece polymer chair.

00:08:25.758 --> 00:08:28.534
What nature does
is it drills holes in things.

00:08:28.558 --> 00:08:29.774
It liberates form.

00:08:29.798 --> 00:08:31.894
It takes away anything extraneous.

00:08:31.918 --> 00:08:33.134
That's what I do.

00:08:33.158 --> 00:08:35.574
I make organic things which are essential.

00:08:35.598 --> 00:08:39.694
And they look funky, too --
but I don't set out to make funky things

00:08:39.718 --> 00:08:41.774
because I think
that's an absolute disgrace.

00:08:41.798 --> 00:08:43.894
I set out to look at natural forms.

00:08:43.918 --> 00:08:47.894
If you took the idea of fractal technology
further, take a membrane,

00:08:47.918 --> 00:08:50.613
shrinking it down constantly
like nature does --

00:08:50.637 --> 00:08:52.214
that could be a seat for a chair.

00:08:52.238 --> 00:08:54.014
It could be a sole for a sports shoe.

00:08:54.038 --> 00:08:56.894
It could be a car blending into seats.

00:08:56.918 --> 00:08:59.574
Wow. Let's go for it.
That's the kind of stuff.

00:08:59.598 --> 00:09:01.414
This is what exists in nature.

00:09:01.438 --> 00:09:06.374
Observation now allows us
to bring that natural process

00:09:06.398 --> 00:09:08.414
into the design process every day.

00:09:08.438 --> 00:09:09.654
That's what I do.

00:09:09.678 --> 00:09:11.734
This is a show
that's currently on in Tokyo.

00:09:11.758 --> 00:09:15.414
It's called "Superliquidity."
It's my sculptural investigation.

00:09:15.438 --> 00:09:18.094
It's like 21st-century Henry Moore.

00:09:18.118 --> 00:09:21.934
When you see a Henry Moore, still,
your hair stands up.

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:24.174
There's some amazing spiritual connect.

00:09:24.198 --> 00:09:28.094
If he was a car designer,
phew, we'd all be driving one.

00:09:28.118 --> 00:09:31.294
In his day, he was
the highest taxpayer in Britain.

00:09:31.318 --> 00:09:33.694
That is the power of organic design.

00:09:33.718 --> 00:09:37.118
It contributes immensely to our --

00:09:38.678 --> 00:09:40.214
sense of being,

00:09:40.238 --> 00:09:42.096
our sense of relationships with things,

00:09:42.120 --> 00:09:44.294
our sensuality and,
you know, the sort of --

00:09:44.318 --> 00:09:48.334
even the sort of socio-erotic side,
which is very important.

00:09:48.358 --> 00:09:50.854
This is my artwork.
This is all my process.

00:09:50.878 --> 00:09:54.894
These actually are sold as artwork.
They're very big prints.

00:09:54.918 --> 00:09:57.414
But this is how I get to that object.

00:09:57.438 --> 00:10:00.614
Ironically, that object was made
by the Killarney process,

00:10:00.638 --> 00:10:03.254
which is a brand-new process here
for the 21st century,

00:10:03.278 --> 00:10:06.294
and I can hear Greg Lynn
laughing his socks off as I say that.

00:10:06.318 --> 00:10:08.014
I'll tell you about that later.

00:10:08.038 --> 00:10:11.814
When I look into these data images,

00:10:11.838 --> 00:10:13.574
I see new things.

00:10:13.598 --> 00:10:16.174
It's self-inspired.

00:10:16.198 --> 00:10:18.054
Diatomic structures, radiolaria,

00:10:18.078 --> 00:10:20.507
the things that we couldn't see
but we can do now --

00:10:20.531 --> 00:10:21.867
these, again, are cored out.

00:10:21.891 --> 00:10:25.294
They're made virtually from nothing.
They're made from silica.

00:10:25.318 --> 00:10:27.494
Why not structures from cars like that?

00:10:27.518 --> 00:10:30.614
Coral, all these natural forces,

00:10:30.638 --> 00:10:35.814
take away what they don't need
and they deliver maximum beauty.

00:10:35.838 --> 00:10:38.094
We need to be in that realm.

00:10:38.118 --> 00:10:40.494
I want to do stuff like that.

00:10:40.518 --> 00:10:43.566
This is a new chair which should
come on the market in September.

00:10:43.590 --> 00:10:47.414
It's for a company called Moroso in Italy.
It's a gas-injected polymer chair.

00:10:47.438 --> 00:10:50.094
Those holes you see there
are very filtered-down,

00:10:50.118 --> 00:10:54.134
watered-down versions of the extremity
of the diatomic structures.

00:10:54.158 --> 00:10:56.682
It goes with the flow
of the polymer and you'll see --

00:10:56.706 --> 00:10:59.694
there's an image coming up
right now that shows the full thing.

00:10:59.718 --> 00:11:03.614
It's great to have companies in Italy
who support this way of dreaming.

00:11:03.638 --> 00:11:05.789
If you see the shadows
that come through that,

00:11:05.813 --> 00:11:08.535
they're actually probably
more important than the product,

00:11:08.559 --> 00:11:09.996
but it's the minimum it takes.

00:11:10.020 --> 00:11:12.294
The coring out of the back
lets you breathe.

00:11:12.318 --> 00:11:14.271
It takes away any material you don't need

00:11:14.295 --> 00:11:16.575
and it actually garners flexure too.

00:11:18.278 --> 00:11:21.374
I was going to break into a dance then.

00:11:21.398 --> 00:11:23.334
This is some current work I'm doing.

00:11:23.358 --> 00:11:25.414
I'm looking at single-surface structures

00:11:25.438 --> 00:11:28.134
and how they stretch and flow.

00:11:28.158 --> 00:11:33.638
It's based on furniture typologies,
but that's not the end motivation.

00:11:33.998 --> 00:11:35.598
It's made from aluminum ...

00:11:36.758 --> 00:11:40.014
as opposed to aluminium, and it's grown.

00:11:40.038 --> 00:11:41.254
It's grown in my mind,

00:11:41.278 --> 00:11:45.854
and then it's grown in terms
of the whole process that I go through.

00:11:45.878 --> 00:11:50.534
This is two weeks ago in CCP in Coventry,
who build parts for Bentleys and so on.

00:11:50.558 --> 00:11:52.734
It's being built as we speak

00:11:52.758 --> 00:11:55.734
and it will be on show in Phillips
next year in New York.

00:11:55.758 --> 00:11:58.614
I have a big show
with Phillips Auctioneers.

00:11:58.638 --> 00:12:01.614
When I see these animations,
oh Jesus, I'm blown away.

00:12:01.638 --> 00:12:03.654
This is what goes on
in my studio everyday.

00:12:03.678 --> 00:12:05.454
I walk -- I'm traveling. I come back.

00:12:05.478 --> 00:12:08.812
Some guy's got that on a computer --
there's this like, oh my goodness.

00:12:08.836 --> 00:12:12.574
So I try to create this energy
of invention every day in my studio.

00:12:12.598 --> 00:12:14.614
This kind of effervescent --

00:12:14.638 --> 00:12:20.214
fully charged sense of soup
that delivers ideas.

00:12:20.238 --> 00:12:22.214
Single-surface products.

00:12:22.238 --> 00:12:23.934
Furniture's a good one.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.774
How you grow legs out of a surface.

00:12:26.798 --> 00:12:28.418
I would love to build this one day

00:12:28.442 --> 00:12:31.414
and perhaps I'd like
to build it also out of flour, sugar,

00:12:31.438 --> 00:12:35.054
polymer, wood chips --
I don't know, human hair.

00:12:35.078 --> 00:12:38.774
I don't know. I'd love a go at that.
I don't know. If I just got some time.

00:12:38.798 --> 00:12:42.614
That's the weird side coming out again.
A lot of companies don't understand that.

00:12:42.638 --> 00:12:45.334
Three weeks ago I was with Sony in Tokyo.

00:12:45.358 --> 00:12:48.755
They said, "Give us the dream.
What is our dream? How do we beat Apple?"

00:12:48.779 --> 00:12:50.978
I said, "You don't copy Apple,
that's for sure.

00:12:51.002 --> 00:12:52.262
You get into biopolymers."

00:12:52.286 --> 00:12:53.921
They looked straight through me.

00:12:54.878 --> 00:12:56.694
What a waste. Anyway.

00:12:56.718 --> 00:12:57.934
(Laughter)

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:01.174
No, it's true. Fuck them.
You know, I mean --

00:13:01.198 --> 00:13:02.534
(Laughter)

00:13:02.558 --> 00:13:04.774
I'm delivering; they're not taking.

00:13:04.798 --> 00:13:06.334
I've had this image 20 years.

00:13:06.358 --> 00:13:09.974
I've had this image of a water droplet
for 20 years, sitting on a hot bed.

00:13:09.998 --> 00:13:11.774
That is an image of a car for me.

00:13:11.798 --> 00:13:14.179
That's the car of the future.
It's a water droplet.

00:13:14.203 --> 00:13:16.774
I've been banging on about this
like I can't believe.

00:13:16.798 --> 00:13:18.014
Cars are all wrong.

00:13:18.038 --> 00:13:20.277
I'm going to show you
something a bit weird now.

00:13:20.301 --> 00:13:22.894
They laughed everywhere
over the world I showed this.

00:13:22.918 --> 00:13:24.974
The only place
that didn't laugh was Moscow.

00:13:24.998 --> 00:13:26.814
Cars are made from 30,000 components.

00:13:26.838 --> 00:13:32.494
How ridiculous is that?
Couldn't you make that from 300?

00:13:32.518 --> 00:13:35.654
It's got a vacuum-formed,
carbon-nylon pan.

00:13:35.678 --> 00:13:39.210
Everything's holistically integrated.
It opens and closes like a bread bin.

00:13:39.234 --> 00:13:41.717
There is no engine.
There's a solar panel on the back

00:13:41.741 --> 00:13:45.041
and there are batteries in the wheels;
they're fitted like Formula 1.

00:13:45.065 --> 00:13:47.875
You take them off your wall,
you plug them in. Off you go.

00:13:47.899 --> 00:13:50.614
A three-wheeled car: slow, feminine,

00:13:50.638 --> 00:13:52.877
transparent, so you can see
the people in there.

00:13:52.901 --> 00:13:54.378
You drive different.

00:13:54.402 --> 00:13:56.574
You see that thing. You do. You do.

00:13:56.598 --> 00:13:59.294
And not anesthetized, separated from life.

00:13:59.318 --> 00:14:02.614
There's a hole at the front
and there's a reason for that.

00:14:02.638 --> 00:14:06.054
It's a city car.
You drive along. You get out.

00:14:06.078 --> 00:14:08.678
You drive on to a proboscis. You get out.

00:14:09.918 --> 00:14:11.134
It lifts you up.

00:14:11.158 --> 00:14:14.674
It presents the solar panel to the sun,
and at night, it's a street lamp.

00:14:14.698 --> 00:14:18.854
(Applause)

00:14:18.878 --> 00:14:21.926
That's what happens if you get inspired
by the street lamp first,

00:14:21.950 --> 00:14:23.134
and do the car second.

00:14:23.158 --> 00:14:25.774
I can see these bubbles
with these hydrogen packages,

00:14:25.798 --> 00:14:30.574
floating around
on the ground, driven by AI.

00:14:30.598 --> 00:14:32.273
When I showed this in South Africa,

00:14:32.297 --> 00:14:35.400
everybody afterwards was going,
"Hey, car on a stick. Like this."

00:14:35.424 --> 00:14:37.084
Can you imagine? A car on a stick.

00:14:37.108 --> 00:14:38.294
(Laughter)

00:14:38.318 --> 00:14:40.934
If you put it next to
contemporary architecture,

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:42.494
it feels totally natural to me.

00:14:42.518 --> 00:14:44.376
And that's what I do with my furniture.

00:14:44.400 --> 00:14:47.534
I'm not putting Charles Eames'
furniture in buildings anymore.

00:14:47.558 --> 00:14:50.151
I'm trying to build furniture
which fits architecture.

00:14:50.175 --> 00:14:52.182
I'm trying to build
transportation systems.

00:14:52.206 --> 00:14:54.500
I work on aircraft for Airbus,

00:14:54.524 --> 00:14:55.814
I do all this sort of stuff

00:14:55.838 --> 00:14:59.614
trying to force these natural,
inspired-by-nature dreams home.

00:14:59.638 --> 00:15:01.414
I'm going to finish on two things.

00:15:01.438 --> 00:15:03.934
This is the stereolithography
of a staircase.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:07.718
It's a little bit of a dedication
to James, James Watson.

00:15:08.878 --> 00:15:10.454
I built this thing for my studio.

00:15:10.478 --> 00:15:13.694
It cost me 250,000 dollars to build this.

00:15:13.718 --> 00:15:16.614
Most people go and buy the Aston Martin.

00:15:16.638 --> 00:15:17.854
I built this.

00:15:17.878 --> 00:15:20.654
This is the data that goes with that.
Incredibly complex.

00:15:20.678 --> 00:15:24.494
Took about two years,
because I'm looking for fat-free design.

00:15:24.518 --> 00:15:28.118
Lean, efficient things. Healthy products.

00:15:29.078 --> 00:15:30.494
This is built by composites.

00:15:30.518 --> 00:15:35.134
It's a single element which rotates around
to create a holistic element,

00:15:35.158 --> 00:15:38.974
and this is a carbon-fiber handrail
which is only supported in two places.

00:15:38.998 --> 00:15:41.894
Modern materials
allow us to do modern things.

00:15:41.918 --> 00:15:43.534
This is a shot in the studio.

00:15:43.558 --> 00:15:46.094
This is how it looks
pretty much every day.

00:15:46.118 --> 00:15:48.894
You wouldn't want to have
a fear of heights coming down it.

00:15:48.918 --> 00:15:53.294
There is virtually no handrail.
It doesn't pass any standards.

00:15:53.318 --> 00:15:55.374
(Laughter)

00:15:55.398 --> 00:15:56.614
Who cares?

00:15:56.638 --> 00:15:58.054
(Laughter)

00:15:58.078 --> 00:16:00.936
And it has an internal handrail
which gives it its strength.

00:16:00.960 --> 00:16:04.151
It's this holistic integration.
That's my studio. It's subterranean.

00:16:04.175 --> 00:16:06.494
It's in Notting Hill,
next to all the crap --

00:16:06.518 --> 00:16:08.214
the prostitutes and all that stuff.

00:16:08.238 --> 00:16:10.374
It's next to David Hockney's
original studio.

00:16:10.398 --> 00:16:13.073
It has a lighting system
that changes throughout the day.

00:16:13.097 --> 00:16:15.962
My guys go out for lunch.
The door's open. They come back in,

00:16:15.986 --> 00:16:18.921
because it's normally raining
and they prefer to stay in.

00:16:18.945 --> 00:16:20.130
This is my studio.

00:16:20.154 --> 00:16:22.374
Elephant skull
from Oxford University, 1988.

00:16:22.398 --> 00:16:25.018
I bought that last year.
They're very difficult to find.

00:16:25.042 --> 00:16:27.614
If anybody's got a whale skeleton
they want to sell me,

00:16:27.638 --> 00:16:29.174
I'll put it in the studio.

00:16:29.198 --> 00:16:31.534
So I'm just going
to interject a little bit

00:16:31.558 --> 00:16:34.294
with some of the things
that you'll see in the video.

00:16:34.318 --> 00:16:37.614
It's a homemade video, made it myself
at three o'clock in the morning

00:16:37.638 --> 00:16:40.054
just to show you how my real world is.

00:16:40.078 --> 00:16:41.294
You never see that.

00:16:41.318 --> 00:16:44.461
You never see architects or designers
showing you their real world.

00:16:44.485 --> 00:16:45.774
This is called a "Plasnet."

00:16:45.798 --> 00:16:49.654
It's a new bio-polycarbonate chair
I'm doing in Italy.

00:16:49.678 --> 00:16:52.654
World's first bamboo bike
with folding handlebars.

00:16:52.678 --> 00:16:54.454
We should all be riding one of these.

00:16:54.478 --> 00:16:58.574
As China buys all these crappy cars,
we should be riding things like this.

00:16:58.598 --> 00:16:59.798
Counterbalance.

00:17:01.318 --> 00:17:02.534
Like I say, it's a cross

00:17:02.558 --> 00:17:05.774
between Natural History Museum
and a NASA laboratory.

00:17:05.798 --> 00:17:07.974
It's full of prototypes and objects.

00:17:07.998 --> 00:17:09.668
It's self-inspirational, again.

00:17:09.692 --> 00:17:11.567
I mean, the rare times when I'm there,

00:17:11.591 --> 00:17:13.174
I do enjoy it.

00:17:13.198 --> 00:17:17.054
And I get lots and lots of kids coming.

00:17:17.077 --> 00:17:22.294
I'm a contaminator for all those children
of investment bankers -- wankers.

00:17:22.317 --> 00:17:23.534
Sorry.

00:17:23.557 --> 00:17:25.494
(Laughter)

00:17:25.518 --> 00:17:28.334
That's a solar seed.
It's a concept for new architecture.

00:17:28.358 --> 00:17:32.094
That thing on the top is the world's
first solar-powered garden lamp --

00:17:32.118 --> 00:17:33.854
the first produced.

00:17:33.878 --> 00:17:36.054
Giles Revell should be
talking here today --

00:17:36.077 --> 00:17:38.294
amazing photography
of things you can't see.

00:17:38.317 --> 00:17:42.318
The first sculptural model
I made for that thing in Tokyo.

00:17:44.638 --> 00:17:46.734
Lots of stuff.
There's a little leaf chair --

00:17:46.758 --> 00:17:48.758
that golden looking thing
is called "Leaf."

00:17:48.782 --> 00:17:50.334
It's made from Kevlar.

00:17:50.358 --> 00:17:52.494
On the wall is my book
called "Supernatural,"

00:17:52.518 --> 00:17:55.376
which allows me to remember
what I've done, because I forget.

00:17:55.400 --> 00:17:57.974
There's an aerated brick
I did in Limoges last year,

00:17:57.998 --> 00:18:00.438
in Concepts for New Ceramics
in Architecture.

00:18:04.118 --> 00:18:06.934
Gernot Oberfell, working
at three o'clock in the morning --

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:08.358
and I don't pay overtime.

00:18:09.038 --> 00:18:11.934
Overtime is the passion of design,

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:14.734
so join the club or don't.

00:18:14.758 --> 00:18:16.294
(Laughter)

00:18:16.318 --> 00:18:18.318
No, it's true. People like Tom and Greg --

00:18:18.342 --> 00:18:20.723
we're traveling like you can't --
we fit it all in.

00:18:20.747 --> 00:18:22.534
I don't know how we do it.

00:18:22.558 --> 00:18:26.814
Next week I'm at Electrolux in Sweden,
then I'm in Beijing on Friday.

00:18:26.838 --> 00:18:28.374
You work that one out.

00:18:28.398 --> 00:18:32.574
And when I see Ed's photographs,
I think, why the hell am I going to China?

00:18:32.598 --> 00:18:33.814
It's true. It's true.

00:18:33.838 --> 00:18:35.974
Because there's a soul
in this whole thing.

00:18:35.998 --> 00:18:39.494
We need to have a new instinct
for the 21st century.

00:18:39.518 --> 00:18:41.814
We need to combine all this stuff.

00:18:41.838 --> 00:18:44.534
If all the people who were
talking over this period

00:18:44.558 --> 00:18:45.774
worked on a car together,

00:18:45.798 --> 00:18:48.478
it would be a joy, absolute joy.

00:18:49.998 --> 00:18:52.838
So there's a new X-light system
I'm doing in Japan.

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:58.654
There's Tuareg shoes from North Africa.
There's a Kifwebe mask.

00:18:58.678 --> 00:19:00.238
These are my sculptures.

00:19:01.198 --> 00:19:02.894
A copper jelly mold.

00:19:02.918 --> 00:19:04.654
(Laughter)

00:19:04.678 --> 00:19:07.250
It sounds like some quiz show
or something, doesn't it?

00:19:09.398 --> 00:19:10.598
So, it's going to end.

00:19:12.718 --> 00:19:15.238
Thank you, James,
for your great inspiration.

00:19:21.318 --> 00:19:22.574
Thank you very much.

00:19:22.598 --> 00:19:25.198
(Applause)

title: The birth of Wikipedia
transcript: Charles Van Doren, who was later a senior editor of Britannica, said the ideal encyclopedia should be radical — it should stop being safe. But if you know anything about the history of Britannica since 1962, it was anything but radical: still a very completely safe, stodgy type of encyclopedia. Wikipedia, on the other hand, begins with a very radical idea, and that's for all of us to imagine a world in which every single person on the planet is given free access to the sum of all human knowledge.And that's what we're doing. So Wikipedia — you just saw the little demonstration of it — it's a freely licensed encyclopedia. It's written by thousands of volunteers all over the world in many, many languages. It's written using wiki software — which is the type of software he just demonstrated — so anyone can quickly edit and save, and it goes live on the Internet immediately. And everything about Wikipedia is managed by virtually an all-volunteer staff. So when Yochai is talking about new methods of organization, he's exactly describing Wikipedia. And what I'm going to do today is tell you a little bit more about how it really works on the inside.So Wikipedia's owned by the Wikimedia Foundation, which I founded, a nonprofit organization. And our goal, the core aim of the Wikimedia Foundation, is to get a free encyclopedia to every single person on the planet. And so, if you think about what that means, it means a lot more than just building a cool website. We're really interested in all the issues of the digital divide, poverty worldwide, empowering people everywhere to have the information that they need to make good decisions. And so we're going to have to do a lot of work that goes beyond just the Internet. And so that's a big part of why we've chosen the free licensing model, because that empowers local entrepreneurs or anyone who wants to — they can take our content and do anything they like with it — you can copy it, redistribute it — and you can do it commercially or non-commercially.So there's a lot of opportunities that are going to arise around Wikipedia all over the world. We're funded by donations from the public, and one of the more interesting things about that is how little money it actually takes to run Wikipedia. So Yochai showed you the graph of what the cost of a printing press was. And I'm going to tell you what the cost of Wikipedia is. But first, I'll show you how big it is. So we've got over 600,000 articles in English. We've got two million total articles across many, many different languages. The biggest languages are German, Japanese, French — all the Western-European languages are quite big. But only around one-third of all of our traffic to our web clusters to the English Wikipedia, which is surprising to a lot of people. A lot of people think in a very English-centric way on the Internet, but for us, we're truly global. We're in many, many languages. How popular we've gotten to be — we're a top-50 website and we're more popular than the New York Times. So this is where we get to Yochai's discussion.This shows the growth of Wikipedia — we're the blue line there — and this is the New York Times over there. And what's interesting about this is the New York Times website is a huge, enormous corporate operation with I have no idea how many hundreds of employees. We have exactly one employee, and that employee is our lead software developer. And he's only been our employee since January 2005, all the other growth before that ... So the servers are managed by a ragtag band of volunteers. All the editing is done by volunteers. And the way that we're organized is not like any traditional organization you can imagine. People are always asking, "Well, who's in charge of this?" or "Who does that?" And the answer is: anybody who wants to pitch in. It's a very unusual and chaotic thing. We've got over 90 servers now in three locations. These are managed by volunteer system administrators who are online. I can go online any time of the day or night and see eight to 10 people waiting for me to ask a question or something, anything about the servers. You could never afford to do this in a company. You could never afford to have a standby crew of people 24 hours a day and do what we're doing at Wikipedia.So we're doing around 1.4 billion page views monthly, so it's really gotten to be a huge thing. And everything is managed by the volunteers. And the total monthly cost for our bandwidth is about 5,000 dollars. And that's essentially our main cost. We could actually do without the employee. We hired Brian because he was working part-time for two years and full-time at Wikipedia, so we actually hired him, so he could get a life and go to the movies sometimes. So the big question when you've got this really chaotic organization is, why isn't it all rubbish? Why is the website as good as it is?First of all, how good is it? Well, it's pretty good. It isn't perfect, but it's much better than you would expect, given our completely chaotic model. So when you saw him make a ridiculous edit to the page about me, you think, "Oh, this is obviously just going to degenerate into rubbish." But when we've seen quality tests — and there haven't been enough of these yet and I'm really encouraging people to do more, comparing Wikipedia to traditional things — we win hands down.So a German magazine compared German Wikipedia, which is much, much smaller than English, to Microsoft Encarta and to Brockhaus multimedial, and we won across the board. They hired experts to come and look at articles and compare the quality, and we were very pleased with that result.So a lot of people have heard about the Wikipedia Bush-Kerry controversy. The media has covered this somewhat extensively. It started out with an article in Red Herring. The reporters called me up and they — I mean, I have to say they spelled my name right, but they really wanted to say the Bush-Kerry election is so contentious, it's tearing apart the Wikipedia community. And so they quote me as saying, "They're the most contentious in the history of Wikipedia." What I actually said is they're not contentious at all. So it's a slight misquote.(Laughter)The articles were edited quite heavily. And it is true that we did have to lock the articles on a couple of occasions. Time magazine recently reported that "Extreme action sometimes has to be taken, and Wales locked the entries on Kerry and Bush for most of 2004." This came after I told the reporter that we had to lock it for — occasionally a little bit here and there. So the truth in general is that the kinds of controversies that you would probably think we have within the Wikipedia community are not really controversies at all.Articles on controversial topics are edited a lot, but they don't cause much controversy within the community. And the reason for this is that most people understand the need for neutrality. The real struggle is not between the right and the left — that's where most people assume — but it's between the party of the thoughtful and the party of the jerks. And no side of the political spectrum has a monopoly on either of those qualities. The actual truth about the specific Bush-Kerry incident is that the Bush-Kerry articles were locked less than one percent of the time in 2004, and it wasn't because they were contentious; it was just because there was routine vandalism — which happens sometimes even on stage ...(Laughter)Sometimes even reporters have reported to me that they vandalized Wikipedia and were amazed that it was fixed so quickly. And I said — you know, I always say, please don't do that. That's not a good thing. So how do we do this? How do we manage the quality control? How does it work?So there's a few elements, mostly social policies and some elements of the software. So the biggest and the most important thing is our neutral point of view policy. This is something that I set down, from the very beginning, as a core principle of the community that's completely not debatable. It's a social concept of cooperation, so we don't talk a lot about truth and objectivity. The reason for this is if we say we're only going to write the "truth" about some topic, that doesn't do us a damn bit of good of figuring out what to write, because I don't agree with you about what's the truth. But we have this jargon term of neutrality, which has its own long history within the community, which basically says, any time there's a controversial issue, Wikipedia itself should not take a stand on the issue. We should merely report on what reputable parties have said about it. So this neutrality policy is really important for us because it empowers a community that is very diverse to come together and actually get some work done.So we have very diverse contributors in terms of political, religious, cultural backgrounds. By having this firm neutrality policy, which is non-negotiable from the beginning, we ensure that people can work together and that the entries don't become simply a war back and forth between the left and the right. If you engage in that type of behavior, you'll be asked to leave the community.So, real-time peer review. Every single change on the site goes to the "Recent changes" page. So as soon as he made his change, it went to the "Recent changes" page. That recent changes page was also fed into an IRC channel, which is an Internet chat channel that people are monitoring with various software tools. And people can get RSS feeds — they can get email notifications of changes. And then users can set up their own personal watch list. So my page is on quite a few volunteers' watch lists, because it is sometimes vandalized. And therefore, what happens is someone will notice the change very quickly, and then they'll just simply revert the change.There's a "new pages feed," for example, so you can go to a certain page of Wikipedia and see every new page as it's created. This is really important because a lot of new pages are just garbage that has to be deleted, you know, "ASDFASDF." But also, that's some of the most interesting and fun things, some of the new articles. People will start an article on some interesting topic, other people will find that intriguing and jump in and help and make it much better.So we do have edits by anonymous users, which is one of the most controversial and intriguing things about Wikipedia. So, Chris was able to do his change — he didn't have to log in or anything; he just went on the website and made a change. But it turns out that only about 18 percent of all the edits to the website are done by anonymous users. And that's a really important thing to understand: the vast majority of the edits that go on on the website are from a very close-knit community of maybe 600 to 1,000 people who are in constant communication. And we have over 40 IRC channels, 40 mailing lists. All these people know each other. They communicate. We have off-line meetings.These are the people who are doing the bulk of the site, and they are, in a sense, semi-professionals at what they're doing. The standards we set for ourselves are equal to or higher than professional standards of quality. We don't always meet those standards, but that's what we're striving for.And so that tight community is who really cares for the site, and these are some of the smartest people I've ever met. It's my job to say that, but it's actually true. The type of people who were drawn to writing an encyclopedia for fun tend to be pretty smart people.The tools and the software: there's lots of tools that allow us — allow us, meaning the community — to self-monitor and to monitor all the work. This is an example of a page history on "flat Earth," and you can see some changes that were made. What's nice about this page is you can immediately take a look at this and see, "OK, I understand now." When somebody goes and looks at — they see that someone, an anonymous IP number, made an edit to my page. That sounds suspicious. Who is this person? Somebody looks at it — they can immediately see highlighted in red all of the changes that took place — to see, OK, well, these words have changed, things like this. So that's one tool that we can use to very quickly monitor the history of a page.Another thing that we do within the community is we leave everything very open-ended. Most of the social rules and the methods of work are left completely open-ended in the software. All of that stuff is just on Wiki pages. And so there's nothing in the software that enforces the rules. The example I've got up here is the Votes for Deletion page. So, I mentioned earlier, people type "ASDFASDF" — it needs to be deleted. Cases like that, the administrators just delete it. There's no reason to have a big argument about it. But you can imagine there's a lot of other areas where the question is, is this notable enough to go in an encyclopedia? Is the information verifiable? Is it a hoax? Is it true? Is it what? So we needed a social method for figuring out the answer to this. And so the method that arose organically within the community is the Votes For Deletion page. And in the particular example we have here, it's a film, "Twisted Issues," and the first person says, "Now this is supposedly a film. It fails the Google test miserably." The Google test is you look in Google and see if it's there, because if something's not even in Google, it probably doesn't exist at all. It's not a perfect rule, but it's a nice starting point for quick research. So somebody says, "Delete it, please. Delete it — it's not notable." And then somebody says, "Wait, I found it. I found it in a book, 'Film Threat Video Guide: the 20 Underground Films You Must See.'" So the next persons says, "Clean it up." Somebody says, "I've found it on IMDB. Keep, keep, keep."And what's interesting about this is that the software is — these votes are just text typed into a page. This is not really a vote so much as it is a dialogue. Now it is true that at the end of the day, an administrator can go through here and take a look at this and say, "OK, 18 deletes, two keeps: we'll delete it." But in other cases, this could be 18 deletes and two keeps, and we would keep it, because if those last two keeps say, "Wait a minute. Nobody else saw this but I found it in a book, and I found a link to a page that describes it, and I'm going to clean it up tomorrow, so please don't delete it," then it would survive.And it also matters who the people are who are voting. Like I say, it's a tight-knit community. Down here at the bottom, "Keep, real movie," RickK. RickK is a very famous Wikipedian who does an enormous amount of work with vandalism, hoaxes and votes for deletion. His voice carries a lot of weight within the community because he knows what he's doing. So how is all this governed? People really want to know about administrators, things like that. So the Wikipedia governance model, the governance of the community, is a very confusing, but workable mix of consensus — meaning we try not to vote on the content of articles, because the majority view is not necessarily neutral — some amount of democracy — all of the administrators — these are the people who have the ability to delete pages. That doesn't mean that they have the right to delete pages. They still have to follow all the rules — but they're elected by the community.Sometimes people — random trolls on the Internet — like to accuse me of handpicking the administrators to bias the content of the encyclopedia. I always laugh at this, because I have no idea how they're elected, actually. There's a certain amount of aristocracy. You got a hint of that when I mentioned, like, RickK's voice would carry a lot more weight than someone we don't know.I give this talk sometimes with Angela, who was just re-elected to the board from the community — to the Board of the Foundation, with more than twice the votes of the person who didn't make it. And I always embarrass her because I say, "Well, Angela, for example, could get away with doing absolutely anything within Wikipedia, because she's so admired and so powerful." But the irony is, of course, that Angela can do this because she's the one person who you know would never, ever break any rules of Wikipedia. And I also like to say she's the only person who actually knows all the rules of Wikipedia, so ... And then there's monarchy, and that's my role on the community, so ...(Laughter)I was describing this in Berlin once, and the next day in the newspaper the headline said, "I am the Queen of England."(Laughter)And that's not exactly what I said, but —(Laughter)the point is my role in the community — Within the free software world, there's been a long-standing tradition of the "benevolent dictator" model. So if you look at most of the major free software projects, they have one single person in charge who everyone agrees is the benevolent dictator. Well, I don't like the term "benevolent dictator," and I don't think that it's my job or my role in the world of ideas to be the dictator of the future of all human knowledge compiled by the world. It just isn't appropriate. But there is a need still for a certain amount of monarchy, a certain amount of — sometimes we have to make a decision and we don't want to get bogged down too heavily in formal decision-making processes.So as an example of how this can be important: we recently had a situation where a neo-Nazi website discovered Wikipedia, and they said, "Oh, well, this is horrible, this Jewish conspiracy of a website, and we're going to get certain articles deleted that we don't like. And we see they have a voting process, so we're going to send — we have 40,000 members and we're going to send them over and they're all going to vote and get these pages deleted." Well, they managed to get 18 people to show up. That's neo-Nazi math for you. They always think they've got 40,000 members when they've got 18. But they managed to get 18 people to come and vote in a fairly absurd way to delete a perfectly valid article. Of course, the vote ended up being about 85 to 18, so there was no real danger to our democratic processes. On the other hand, people said, "But what are we going to do? I mean, this could happen. What if some group gets really seriously organized and comes in and wants to vote?" Then I said, "Well, fuck it, we'll just change the rules." That's my job in the community: to say we won't allow our openness and freedom to undermine the quality of the content. And so, as long as people trust me in my role, then that's a valid place for me. Of course, because of the free licensing, if I do a bad job, the volunteers are more than happy to take and leave — I can't tell anyone what to do.So the final point here is that to understand how Wikipedia works, it's important to understand that our wiki model is the way we work, but we are not fanatical web anarchists. In fact, we're very flexible about the social methodology, because ultimately, the passion of the community is for the quality of the work, not necessarily for the process that we use to generate it.Thank you.(Applause)Ben Saunders: Yeah, hi, Ben Saunders. Jimmy, you mentioned impartiality being a key to Wikipedia's success. It strikes me that much of the textbooks that are used to educate our children are inherently biased. Have you found Wikipedia being used by teachers and how do you see Wikipedia changing education?Jimmy Wales: Yeah, so, a lot of teachers are beginning to use Wikipedia. There's a media storyline about Wikipedia, which I think is false. It builds on the storyline of bloggers versus newspapers. And the storyline is, there's this crazy thing, Wikipedia, but academics hate it and teachers hate it. And that turns out to not be true. The last time I got an email from a journalist saying, "Why do academics hate Wikipedia?" I sent it from my Harvard email address because I was recently appointed a fellow there. And I said, "Well, they don't all hate it."(Laughter)But I think there's going to be huge impacts. And we actually have a project that I'm personally really excited about, which is the Wikibooks project, which is an effort to create textbooks in all the languages. And that's a much bigger project. It's going to take 20 years or so to come to fruition.But part of that is to fulfill our mission of giving an encyclopedia to every single person on the planet. We don't mean we're going to Spam them with AOL-style CDs. We mean we're going to give them a tool that they can use. And for a lot of people in the world, if I give you an encyclopedia that's written at a university level, it doesn't do you any good without a whole host of literacy materials to build you up to the point where you can actually use it. The Wikibooks project is an effort to do that. And I think that we're going to see — it may not even come from us; there's all kinds of innovation going on. But freely licensed textbooks are the next big thing in education.

We have exactly one employee,

00:03:25.518 --> 00:03:28.134
and that employee
is our lead software developer.

00:03:28.158 --> 00:03:31.334
And he's only been our employee
since January 2005,

00:03:31.358 --> 00:03:33.174
all the other growth before that ...

00:03:33.198 --> 00:03:36.814
So the servers are managed
by a ragtag band of volunteers.

00:03:36.838 --> 00:03:38.814
All the editing is done by volunteers.

00:03:38.838 --> 00:03:40.374
And the way that we're organized

00:03:40.398 --> 00:03:43.081
is not like any traditional
organization you can imagine.

00:03:43.105 --> 00:03:45.820
People are always asking,
"Well, who's in charge of this?"

00:03:45.844 --> 00:03:47.014
or "Who does that?"

00:03:47.038 --> 00:03:49.334
And the answer is:
anybody who wants to pitch in.

00:03:49.358 --> 00:03:52.838
It's a very unusual and chaotic thing.

00:03:53.438 --> 00:03:55.734
We've got over 90 servers now
in three locations.

00:03:55.758 --> 00:04:01.014
These are managed by volunteer
system administrators who are online.

00:04:01.038 --> 00:04:03.094
I can go online
any time of the day or night

00:04:03.118 --> 00:04:07.414
and see eight to 10 people waiting for me

00:04:07.438 --> 00:04:10.974
to ask a question or something,
anything about the servers.

00:04:10.998 --> 00:04:13.334
You could never afford
to do this in a company.

00:04:13.358 --> 00:04:14.574
You could never afford

00:04:14.598 --> 00:04:18.334
to have a standby crew of people
24 hours a day

00:04:18.358 --> 00:04:20.678
and do what we're doing at Wikipedia.

00:04:21.438 --> 00:04:24.654
So we're doing around
1.4 billion page views monthly,

00:04:24.678 --> 00:04:26.718
so it's really gotten to be a huge thing.

00:04:27.318 --> 00:04:29.694
And everything is managed
by the volunteers.

00:04:29.718 --> 00:04:33.934
And the total monthly cost
for our bandwidth is about 5,000 dollars.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.894
And that's essentially our main cost.

00:04:35.918 --> 00:04:38.174
We could actually do without the employee.

00:04:38.198 --> 00:04:42.614
We hired Brian because he was
working part-time for two years

00:04:42.638 --> 00:04:43.934
and full-time at Wikipedia,

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.174
so we actually hired him,

00:04:45.198 --> 00:04:47.838
so he could get a life
and go to the movies sometimes.

00:04:48.913 --> 00:04:52.294
So the big question when you've got
this really chaotic organization is,

00:04:52.318 --> 00:04:53.534
why isn't it all rubbish?

00:04:53.558 --> 00:04:55.478
Why is the website as good as it is?

00:04:55.953 --> 00:04:57.334
First of all, how good is it?

00:04:57.358 --> 00:04:58.894
Well, it's pretty good.

00:04:58.918 --> 00:05:00.134
It isn't perfect,

00:05:00.158 --> 00:05:02.174
but it's much better
than you would expect,

00:05:02.198 --> 00:05:03.881
given our completely chaotic model.

00:05:03.905 --> 00:05:06.921
So when you saw him make
a ridiculous edit to the page about me,

00:05:06.945 --> 00:05:10.694
you think, "Oh, this is obviously
just going to degenerate into rubbish."

00:05:10.718 --> 00:05:12.449
But when we've seen quality tests --

00:05:12.473 --> 00:05:14.489
and there haven't been enough of these yet

00:05:14.513 --> 00:05:17.094
and I'm really encouraging
people to do more,

00:05:17.118 --> 00:05:19.254
comparing Wikipedia
to traditional things --

00:05:19.278 --> 00:05:21.054
we win hands down.

00:05:21.078 --> 00:05:23.814
So a German magazine
compared German Wikipedia,

00:05:23.838 --> 00:05:27.174
which is much, much smaller than English,

00:05:27.198 --> 00:05:31.294
to Microsoft Encarta
and to Brockhaus multimedial,

00:05:31.318 --> 00:05:32.774
and we won across the board.

00:05:32.798 --> 00:05:36.179
They hired experts to come and look
at articles and compare the quality,

00:05:36.203 --> 00:05:38.523
and we were very pleased with that result.

00:05:39.278 --> 00:05:44.814
So a lot of people have heard about
the Wikipedia Bush-Kerry controversy.

00:05:44.838 --> 00:05:47.494
The media has covered this
somewhat extensively.

00:05:47.518 --> 00:05:50.334
It started out
with an article in Red Herring.

00:05:50.358 --> 00:05:52.174
The reporters called me up and they --

00:05:52.198 --> 00:05:55.174
I mean, I have to say
they spelled my name right,

00:05:55.198 --> 00:06:00.134
but they really wanted to say
the Bush-Kerry election is so contentious,

00:06:00.158 --> 00:06:02.534
it's tearing apart
the Wikipedia community.

00:06:02.558 --> 00:06:04.054
And so they quote me as saying,

00:06:04.078 --> 00:06:06.974
"They're the most contentious
in the history of Wikipedia."

00:06:06.998 --> 00:06:09.574
What I actually said
is they're not contentious at all.

00:06:09.598 --> 00:06:11.694
So it's a slight misquote.

00:06:11.718 --> 00:06:13.494
(Laughter)

00:06:13.518 --> 00:06:15.534
The articles were edited quite heavily.

00:06:15.558 --> 00:06:18.014
And it is true that we did
have to lock the articles

00:06:18.038 --> 00:06:19.374
on a couple of occasions.

00:06:19.398 --> 00:06:21.774
Time magazine recently reported that

00:06:21.798 --> 00:06:23.814
"Extreme action sometimes has to be taken,

00:06:23.838 --> 00:06:28.694
and Wales locked the entries
on Kerry and Bush for most of 2004."

00:06:28.718 --> 00:06:32.974
This came after I told the reporter
that we had to lock it for --

00:06:32.998 --> 00:06:35.134
occasionally a little bit here and there.

00:06:35.158 --> 00:06:38.534
So the truth in general
is that the kinds of controversies

00:06:38.558 --> 00:06:41.749
that you would probably think
we have within the Wikipedia community

00:06:41.773 --> 00:06:44.494
are not really controversies at all.

00:06:44.518 --> 00:06:47.014
Articles on controversial topics
are edited a lot,

00:06:47.038 --> 00:06:50.014
but they don't cause much controversy
within the community.

00:06:50.038 --> 00:06:53.758
And the reason for this is that most
people understand the need for neutrality.

00:06:54.558 --> 00:07:01.254
The real struggle is not
between the right and the left --

00:07:01.278 --> 00:07:02.898
that's where most people assume --

00:07:02.922 --> 00:07:04.974
but it's between
the party of the thoughtful

00:07:04.998 --> 00:07:06.294
and the party of the jerks.

00:07:06.318 --> 00:07:08.134
And no side of the political spectrum

00:07:08.158 --> 00:07:10.614
has a monopoly
on either of those qualities.

00:07:10.638 --> 00:07:13.214
The actual truth
about the specific Bush-Kerry incident

00:07:13.238 --> 00:07:16.214
is that the Bush-Kerry articles

00:07:16.238 --> 00:07:19.214
were locked less than one percent
of the time in 2004,

00:07:19.238 --> 00:07:21.294
and it wasn't because
they were contentious;

00:07:21.318 --> 00:07:23.654
it was just because
there was routine vandalism --

00:07:23.678 --> 00:07:27.374
which happens sometimes even on stage ...

00:07:27.398 --> 00:07:28.534
(Laughter)

00:07:28.558 --> 00:07:32.094
Sometimes even reporters have reported
to me that they vandalized Wikipedia

00:07:32.118 --> 00:07:34.454
and were amazed
that it was fixed so quickly.

00:07:34.478 --> 00:07:37.254
And I said -- you know, I always say,
please don't do that.

00:07:37.278 --> 00:07:38.854
That's not a good thing.

00:07:38.878 --> 00:07:40.374
So how do we do this?

00:07:40.398 --> 00:07:43.254
How do we manage the quality control?

00:07:43.278 --> 00:07:44.478
How does it work?

00:07:46.078 --> 00:07:47.774
So there's a few elements,

00:07:47.798 --> 00:07:51.054
mostly social policies
and some elements of the software.

00:07:51.078 --> 00:07:53.814
So the biggest
and the most important thing

00:07:53.838 --> 00:07:55.569
is our neutral point of view policy.

00:07:55.593 --> 00:07:58.355
This is something
that I set down, from the very beginning,

00:07:58.379 --> 00:08:02.414
as a core principle of the community
that's completely not debatable.

00:08:02.438 --> 00:08:05.334
It's a social concept of cooperation,

00:08:05.358 --> 00:08:08.854
so we don't talk a lot
about truth and objectivity.

00:08:08.878 --> 00:08:10.934
The reason for this is if we say

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.534
we're only going to write
the "truth" about some topic,

00:08:13.558 --> 00:08:16.765
that doesn't do us a damn bit of good
of figuring out what to write,

00:08:16.789 --> 00:08:19.325
because I don't agree with you
about what's the truth.

00:08:19.349 --> 00:08:21.694
But we have this
jargon term of neutrality,

00:08:21.718 --> 00:08:24.174
which has its own long history
within the community,

00:08:24.198 --> 00:08:27.614
which basically says,
any time there's a controversial issue,

00:08:27.638 --> 00:08:30.214
Wikipedia itself should not
take a stand on the issue.

00:08:30.238 --> 00:08:33.477
We should merely report on what
reputable parties have said about it.

00:08:33.501 --> 00:08:36.574
So this neutrality policy
is really important for us

00:08:36.598 --> 00:08:39.854
because it empowers a community
that is very diverse

00:08:39.878 --> 00:08:42.174
to come together
and actually get some work done.

00:08:42.198 --> 00:08:44.334
So we have very diverse contributors

00:08:44.358 --> 00:08:47.574
in terms of political,
religious, cultural backgrounds.

00:08:47.598 --> 00:08:49.414
By having this firm neutrality policy,

00:08:49.438 --> 00:08:51.454
which is non-negotiable
from the beginning,

00:08:51.478 --> 00:08:53.336
we ensure that people can work together

00:08:53.360 --> 00:08:55.574
and that the entries
don't become simply a war

00:08:55.598 --> 00:08:57.741
back and forth
between the left and the right.

00:08:57.765 --> 00:09:01.480
If you engage in that type of behavior,
you'll be asked to leave the community.

00:09:03.198 --> 00:09:04.654
So, real-time peer review.

00:09:04.678 --> 00:09:07.814
Every single change on the site
goes to the "Recent changes" page.

00:09:07.838 --> 00:09:11.334
So as soon as he made his change,
it went to the "Recent changes" page.

00:09:11.358 --> 00:09:15.334
That recent changes page
was also fed into an IRC channel,

00:09:15.358 --> 00:09:16.934
which is an Internet chat channel

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:20.158
that people are monitoring
with various software tools.

00:09:20.878 --> 00:09:23.334
And people can get RSS feeds --

00:09:23.358 --> 00:09:26.454
they can get email
notifications of changes.

00:09:26.478 --> 00:09:29.134
And then users can set up
their own personal watch list.

00:09:29.158 --> 00:09:31.651
So my page is on quite a few
volunteers' watch lists,

00:09:31.675 --> 00:09:33.371
because it is sometimes vandalized.

00:09:33.395 --> 00:09:39.374
And therefore, what happens is someone
will notice the change very quickly,

00:09:39.398 --> 00:09:42.774
and then they'll just
simply revert the change.

00:09:42.798 --> 00:09:44.714
There's a "new pages feed," for example,

00:09:44.738 --> 00:09:46.794
so you can go
to a certain page of Wikipedia

00:09:46.818 --> 00:09:48.746
and see every new page as it's created.

00:09:48.778 --> 00:09:49.928
This is really important

00:09:49.938 --> 00:09:53.154
because a lot of new pages
are just garbage that has to be deleted,

00:09:53.158 --> 00:09:54.414
you know, "ASDFASDF."

00:09:54.438 --> 00:09:57.354
But also, that's some
of the most interesting and fun things,

00:09:57.378 --> 00:09:58.594
some of the new articles.

00:09:58.618 --> 00:10:01.194
People will start an article
on some interesting topic,

00:10:01.218 --> 00:10:03.034
other people will find that intriguing

00:10:03.058 --> 00:10:05.454
and jump in and help
and make it much better.

00:10:05.478 --> 00:10:07.374
So we do have edits by anonymous users,

00:10:07.398 --> 00:10:11.254
which is one of the most controversial
and intriguing things about Wikipedia.

00:10:11.278 --> 00:10:14.894
So, Chris was able to do his change --
he didn't have to log in or anything;

00:10:14.918 --> 00:10:17.734
he just went on the website
and made a change.

00:10:17.758 --> 00:10:19.814
But it turns out
that only about 18 percent

00:10:19.838 --> 00:10:21.334
of all the edits to the website

00:10:21.358 --> 00:10:22.694
are done by anonymous users.

00:10:22.718 --> 00:10:25.054
And that's a really important
thing to understand:

00:10:25.078 --> 00:10:28.334
the vast majority of the edits
that go on on the website

00:10:28.358 --> 00:10:32.054
are from a very close-knit community
of maybe 600 to 1,000 people

00:10:32.078 --> 00:10:33.698
who are in constant communication.

00:10:33.722 --> 00:10:36.294
And we have over 40 IRC channels,
40 mailing lists.

00:10:36.318 --> 00:10:37.894
All these people know each other.

00:10:37.918 --> 00:10:39.966
They communicate.
We have off-line meetings.

00:10:39.990 --> 00:10:42.610
These are the people
who are doing the bulk of the site,

00:10:42.634 --> 00:10:47.282
and they are, in a sense,
semi-professionals at what they're doing.

00:10:47.918 --> 00:10:50.254
The standards we set for ourselves

00:10:50.278 --> 00:10:53.334
are equal to or higher
than professional standards of quality.

00:10:53.358 --> 00:10:56.874
We don't always meet those standards,
but that's what we're striving for.

00:10:56.898 --> 00:10:59.756
And so that tight community
is who really cares for the site,

00:10:59.780 --> 00:11:02.414
and these are some
of the smartest people I've ever met.

00:11:02.438 --> 00:11:04.694
It's my job to say that,
but it's actually true.

00:11:04.718 --> 00:11:08.454
The type of people who were drawn
to writing an encyclopedia for fun

00:11:08.478 --> 00:11:10.814
tend to be pretty smart people.

00:11:10.838 --> 00:11:13.934
The tools and the software:
there's lots of tools that allow us --

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.578
allow us, meaning the community --

00:11:15.602 --> 00:11:17.654
to self-monitor
and to monitor all the work.

00:11:17.678 --> 00:11:20.174
This is an example
of a page history on "flat Earth,"

00:11:20.198 --> 00:11:22.254
and you can see some changes
that were made.

00:11:22.278 --> 00:11:25.574
What's nice about this page
is you can immediately take a look at this

00:11:25.598 --> 00:11:27.174
and see, "OK, I understand now."

00:11:27.198 --> 00:11:28.974
When somebody goes and looks at --

00:11:28.998 --> 00:11:31.141
they see that someone,
an anonymous IP number,

00:11:31.165 --> 00:11:32.654
made an edit to my page.

00:11:32.678 --> 00:11:34.734
That sounds suspicious.
Who is this person?

00:11:34.758 --> 00:11:35.974
Somebody looks at it --

00:11:35.998 --> 00:11:38.014
they can immediately see
highlighted in red

00:11:38.038 --> 00:11:39.934
all of the changes that took place --

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:43.574
to see, OK, well, these words
have changed, things like this.

00:11:43.598 --> 00:11:45.218
So that's one tool that we can use

00:11:45.242 --> 00:11:47.762
to very quickly monitor
the history of a page.

00:11:48.478 --> 00:11:50.774
Another thing that we do
within the community

00:11:50.798 --> 00:11:54.174
is we leave everything very open-ended.

00:11:54.198 --> 00:11:57.574
Most of the social rules
and the methods of work

00:11:57.598 --> 00:12:00.014
are left completely open-ended
in the software.

00:12:00.038 --> 00:12:02.054
All of that stuff is just on Wiki pages.

00:12:02.078 --> 00:12:05.174
And so there's nothing
in the software that enforces the rules.

00:12:05.198 --> 00:12:09.214
The example I've got up here
is the Votes for Deletion page.

00:12:09.238 --> 00:12:11.814
So, I mentioned earlier,
people type "ASDFASDF" --

00:12:11.838 --> 00:12:13.054
it needs to be deleted.

00:12:13.078 --> 00:12:15.554
Cases like that,
the administrators just delete it.

00:12:15.578 --> 00:12:17.914
There's no reason
to have a big argument about it.

00:12:17.938 --> 00:12:21.273
But you can imagine there's a lot
of other areas where the question is,

00:12:21.297 --> 00:12:23.537
is this notable enough
to go in an encyclopedia?

00:12:23.561 --> 00:12:27.134
Is the information verifiable?
Is it a hoax? Is it true? Is it what?

00:12:27.158 --> 00:12:30.214
So we needed a social method
for figuring out the answer to this.

00:12:30.238 --> 00:12:33.096
And so the method that arose
organically within the community

00:12:33.120 --> 00:12:34.694
is the Votes For Deletion page.

00:12:34.718 --> 00:12:36.734
And in the particular
example we have here,

00:12:36.758 --> 00:12:38.254
it's a film, "Twisted Issues,"

00:12:38.278 --> 00:12:39.734
and the first person says,

00:12:39.758 --> 00:12:43.454
"Now this is supposedly a film.
It fails the Google test miserably."

00:12:43.478 --> 00:12:46.294
The Google test is you look in Google
and see if it's there,

00:12:46.318 --> 00:12:50.214
because if something's not even in Google,
it probably doesn't exist at all.

00:12:50.238 --> 00:12:51.814
It's not a perfect rule,

00:12:51.838 --> 00:12:55.174
but it's a nice starting point
for quick research.

00:12:55.198 --> 00:12:58.453
So somebody says, "Delete it, please.
Delete it -- it's not notable."

00:12:58.477 --> 00:13:01.493
And then somebody says,
"Wait, I found it. I found it in a book,

00:13:01.517 --> 00:13:04.774
'Film Threat Video Guide:
the 20 Underground Films You Must See.'"

00:13:04.798 --> 00:13:06.703
So the next persons says, "Clean it up."

00:13:06.727 --> 00:13:10.134
Somebody says, "I've found it on IMDB.
Keep, keep, keep."

00:13:10.158 --> 00:13:12.974
And what's interesting about this
is that the software is --

00:13:12.998 --> 00:13:16.534
these votes are just text
typed into a page.

00:13:16.558 --> 00:13:20.614
This is not really a vote
so much as it is a dialogue.

00:13:20.638 --> 00:13:23.374
Now it is true that at the end of the day,

00:13:23.398 --> 00:13:26.637
an administrator can go through here
and take a look at this and say,

00:13:26.661 --> 00:13:29.134
"OK, 18 deletes, two keeps:
we'll delete it."

00:13:29.158 --> 00:13:32.934
But in other cases,
this could be 18 deletes and two keeps,

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.754
and we would keep it,
because if those last two keeps say,

00:13:35.778 --> 00:13:38.683
"Wait a minute. Nobody else saw this
but I found it in a book,

00:13:38.707 --> 00:13:40.905
and I found a link
to a page that describes it,

00:13:40.929 --> 00:13:44.025
and I'm going to clean it up tomorrow,
so please don't delete it,"

00:13:44.049 --> 00:13:45.234
then it would survive.

00:13:45.258 --> 00:13:47.854
And it also matters
who the people are who are voting.

00:13:47.878 --> 00:13:49.783
Like I say, it's a tight-knit community.

00:13:49.807 --> 00:13:52.334
Down here at the bottom,
"Keep, real movie," RickK.

00:13:52.358 --> 00:13:55.739
RickK is a very famous Wikipedian
who does an enormous amount of work

00:13:55.763 --> 00:13:58.494
with vandalism, hoaxes
and votes for deletion.

00:13:58.518 --> 00:14:01.334
His voice carries a lot of weight
within the community

00:14:01.358 --> 00:14:02.930
because he knows what he's doing.

00:14:04.358 --> 00:14:06.294
So how is all this governed?

00:14:06.318 --> 00:14:09.454
People really want to know
about administrators, things like that.

00:14:09.478 --> 00:14:13.334
So the Wikipedia governance model,
the governance of the community,

00:14:13.358 --> 00:14:17.774
is a very confusing,
but workable mix of consensus --

00:14:17.798 --> 00:14:20.334
meaning we try not to vote
on the content of articles,

00:14:20.358 --> 00:14:24.254
because the majority view
is not necessarily neutral --

00:14:24.278 --> 00:14:25.574
some amount of democracy --

00:14:25.598 --> 00:14:26.934
all of the administrators --

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.754
these are the people
who have the ability to delete pages.

00:14:29.778 --> 00:14:32.614
That doesn't mean that they have
the right to delete pages.

00:14:32.638 --> 00:14:36.474
They still have to follow all the rules --
but they're elected by the community.

00:14:36.498 --> 00:14:38.928
Sometimes people --
random trolls on the Internet --

00:14:38.952 --> 00:14:41.335
like to accuse me
of handpicking the administrators

00:14:41.359 --> 00:14:43.264
to bias the content of the encyclopedia.

00:14:43.288 --> 00:14:47.054
I always laugh at this, because I have
no idea how they're elected, actually.

00:14:47.078 --> 00:14:49.054
There's a certain amount of aristocracy.

00:14:49.078 --> 00:14:51.221
You got a hint of that
when I mentioned, like,

00:14:51.245 --> 00:14:53.397
RickK's voice would carry
a lot more weight

00:14:53.421 --> 00:14:54.717
than someone we don't know.

00:14:54.741 --> 00:14:57.454
I give this talk sometimes with Angela,

00:14:57.478 --> 00:15:00.209
who was just re-elected to the board
from the community --

00:15:00.233 --> 00:15:01.729
to the Board of the Foundation,

00:15:01.753 --> 00:15:04.894
with more than twice the votes
of the person who didn't make it.

00:15:04.918 --> 00:15:07.854
And I always embarrass her because I say,

00:15:07.878 --> 00:15:09.174
"Well, Angela, for example,

00:15:09.198 --> 00:15:12.614
could get away with doing
absolutely anything within Wikipedia,

00:15:12.638 --> 00:15:14.654
because she's so admired and so powerful."

00:15:14.678 --> 00:15:18.494
But the irony is, of course, that Angela
can do this because she's the one person

00:15:18.518 --> 00:15:21.494
who you know would never, ever
break any rules of Wikipedia.

00:15:21.518 --> 00:15:23.574
And I also like to say
she's the only person

00:15:23.598 --> 00:15:26.814
who actually knows
all the rules of Wikipedia, so ...

00:15:26.838 --> 00:15:28.077
And then there's monarchy,

00:15:28.101 --> 00:15:30.117
and that's my role
on the community, so ...

00:15:30.141 --> 00:15:32.534
(Laughter)

00:15:32.558 --> 00:15:35.174
I was describing this in Berlin once,

00:15:35.198 --> 00:15:37.974
and the next day
in the newspaper the headline said,

00:15:37.998 --> 00:15:39.566
"I am the Queen of England."

00:15:39.590 --> 00:15:40.741
(Laughter)

00:15:40.765 --> 00:15:43.134
And that's not exactly what I said, but --

00:15:43.158 --> 00:15:44.654
(Laughter)

00:15:44.678 --> 00:15:47.254
the point is my role in the community --

00:15:47.278 --> 00:15:51.974
Within the free software world,
there's been a long-standing tradition

00:15:51.998 --> 00:15:55.214
of the "benevolent dictator" model.

00:15:55.238 --> 00:15:58.094
So if you look at most
of the major free software projects,

00:15:58.118 --> 00:15:59.894
they have one single person in charge

00:15:59.918 --> 00:16:03.254
who everyone agrees
is the benevolent dictator.

00:16:03.278 --> 00:16:05.774
Well, I don't like the term
"benevolent dictator,"

00:16:05.798 --> 00:16:09.774
and I don't think that it's my job
or my role in the world of ideas

00:16:09.798 --> 00:16:13.134
to be the dictator of the future
of all human knowledge

00:16:13.158 --> 00:16:14.374
compiled by the world.

00:16:14.398 --> 00:16:16.094
It just isn't appropriate.

00:16:16.118 --> 00:16:18.894
But there is a need still
for a certain amount of monarchy,

00:16:18.918 --> 00:16:20.494
a certain amount of --

00:16:20.518 --> 00:16:22.294
sometimes we have to make a decision

00:16:22.318 --> 00:16:24.557
and we don't want
to get bogged down too heavily

00:16:24.581 --> 00:16:27.294
in formal decision-making processes.

00:16:27.318 --> 00:16:32.214
So as an example
of how this can be important:

00:16:32.238 --> 00:16:36.214
we recently had a situation where
a neo-Nazi website discovered Wikipedia,

00:16:36.238 --> 00:16:39.094
and they said,
"Oh, well, this is horrible,

00:16:39.118 --> 00:16:41.014
this Jewish conspiracy of a website,

00:16:41.038 --> 00:16:44.197
and we're going to get certain articles
deleted that we don't like.

00:16:44.221 --> 00:16:47.221
And we see they have a voting process,
so we're going to send --

00:16:47.245 --> 00:16:50.054
we have 40,000 members
and we're going to send them over

00:16:50.078 --> 00:16:52.856
and they're all going to vote
and get these pages deleted."

00:16:52.880 --> 00:16:55.071
Well, they managed
to get 18 people to show up.

00:16:55.095 --> 00:16:57.854
That's neo-Nazi math for you.

00:16:57.878 --> 00:17:01.334
They always think they've got
40,000 members when they've got 18.

00:17:01.358 --> 00:17:04.854
But they managed to get 18 people
to come and vote in a fairly absurd way

00:17:04.878 --> 00:17:06.894
to delete a perfectly valid article.

00:17:06.918 --> 00:17:09.654
Of course, the vote ended up
being about 85 to 18,

00:17:09.678 --> 00:17:12.934
so there was no real danger
to our democratic processes.

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:16.253
On the other hand, people said,
"But what are we going to do?

00:17:16.277 --> 00:17:17.533
I mean, this could happen.

00:17:17.557 --> 00:17:19.894
What if some group
gets really seriously organized

00:17:19.918 --> 00:17:22.494
and comes in and wants to vote?"

00:17:22.518 --> 00:17:25.293
Then I said, "Well, fuck it,
we'll just change the rules."

00:17:25.317 --> 00:17:27.013
That's my job in the community:

00:17:27.037 --> 00:17:30.614
to say we won't allow
our openness and freedom

00:17:30.638 --> 00:17:33.214
to undermine the quality of the content.

00:17:33.238 --> 00:17:36.533
And so, as long as people
trust me in my role,

00:17:36.557 --> 00:17:38.414
then that's a valid place for me.

00:17:38.438 --> 00:17:40.474
Of course, because of the free licensing,

00:17:40.498 --> 00:17:43.975
if I do a bad job, the volunteers
are more than happy to take and leave --

00:17:43.999 --> 00:17:45.479
I can't tell anyone what to do.

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:50.654
So the final point here
is that to understand how Wikipedia works,

00:17:50.678 --> 00:17:53.869
it's important to understand
that our wiki model is the way we work,

00:17:53.893 --> 00:17:57.494
but we are not fanatical web anarchists.

00:17:57.518 --> 00:18:00.894
In fact, we're very flexible
about the social methodology,

00:18:00.918 --> 00:18:03.334
because ultimately,
the passion of the community

00:18:03.358 --> 00:18:05.374
is for the quality of the work,

00:18:05.398 --> 00:18:08.374
not necessarily for the process
that we use to generate it.

00:18:08.398 --> 00:18:09.614
Thank you.

00:18:09.638 --> 00:18:13.894
(Applause)

00:18:13.918 --> 00:18:15.694
Ben Saunders: Yeah, hi, Ben Saunders.

00:18:15.718 --> 00:18:19.854
Jimmy, you mentioned impartiality
being a key to Wikipedia's success.

00:18:19.878 --> 00:18:25.214
It strikes me that much of the textbooks
that are used to educate our children

00:18:25.238 --> 00:18:27.014
are inherently biased.

00:18:27.038 --> 00:18:30.654
Have you found Wikipedia
being used by teachers

00:18:30.678 --> 00:18:33.134
and how do you see Wikipedia
changing education?

00:18:33.158 --> 00:18:37.374
Jimmy Wales: Yeah, so, a lot of teachers
are beginning to use Wikipedia.

00:18:37.398 --> 00:18:41.974
There's a media storyline about Wikipedia,
which I think is false.

00:18:41.998 --> 00:18:45.574
It builds on the storyline
of bloggers versus newspapers.

00:18:45.598 --> 00:18:48.734
And the storyline is,
there's this crazy thing, Wikipedia,

00:18:48.758 --> 00:18:52.214
but academics hate it
and teachers hate it.

00:18:52.238 --> 00:18:54.814
And that turns out to not be true.

00:18:54.838 --> 00:18:57.374
The last time I got an email
from a journalist saying,

00:18:57.398 --> 00:18:59.114
"Why do academics hate Wikipedia?"

00:18:59.138 --> 00:19:00.996
I sent it from my Harvard email address

00:19:01.020 --> 00:19:03.273
because I was recently
appointed a fellow there.

00:19:03.297 --> 00:19:05.313
And I said, "Well,
they don't all hate it."

00:19:05.337 --> 00:19:06.414
(Laughter)

00:19:06.438 --> 00:19:09.294
But I think there's going
to be huge impacts.

00:19:09.318 --> 00:19:12.734
And we actually have a project
that I'm personally really excited about,

00:19:12.758 --> 00:19:14.254
which is the Wikibooks project,

00:19:14.278 --> 00:19:17.374
which is an effort to create
textbooks in all the languages.

00:19:17.398 --> 00:19:18.974
And that's a much bigger project.

00:19:18.998 --> 00:19:23.614
It's going to take 20 years or so
to come to fruition.

00:19:23.638 --> 00:19:25.654
But part of that is to fulfill our mission

00:19:25.678 --> 00:19:28.654
of giving an encyclopedia
to every single person on the planet.

00:19:28.678 --> 00:19:31.534
We don't mean we're going
to Spam them with AOL-style CDs.

00:19:31.558 --> 00:19:34.354
We mean we're going to give them
a tool that they can use.

00:19:34.378 --> 00:19:36.154
And for a lot of people in the world,

00:19:36.178 --> 00:19:39.354
if I give you an encyclopedia
that's written at a university level,

00:19:39.378 --> 00:19:42.934
it doesn't do you any good
without a whole host of literacy materials

00:19:42.958 --> 00:19:45.734
to build you up to the point
where you can actually use it.

00:19:45.758 --> 00:19:47.901
The Wikibooks project
is an effort to do that.

00:19:47.925 --> 00:19:51.134
And I think that we're going to see --
it may not even come from us;

00:19:51.158 --> 00:19:53.134
there's all kinds of innovation going on.

00:19:53.158 --> 00:19:56.318
But freely licensed textbooks
are the next big thing in education.
